150462023.review:
It would be easy for me to just quote the Milkman for this review but since I am lactose intolerant, I am legally obligated to critique this game seriously. Psychonauts is possibly the greatest creation of Tim Schafer, the madman behind hits such as Day of the Tentacle, Grim Fandango and The Secret of Monkey Island. He is one of the few writers in the entire industry capable of not only funny dialogue, but writing that stands the test of time, and there is perhaps no greater example of that than this title.

Psychonauts dives into topics such as psychological health, mental illness, conspiracies and psyops with such a candid and meticulous approach, you'd have no idea this game came out in 2005 from the script alone. The level designs are memorable set pieces dripping in personality and charm, and the bar of quality is so high, you'd think this game was released during the golden era of platforming. It's a title that effortlessly brings to life its themes and concepts into an interactive medium, as if a higher power were given a paintbrush, an easel, and a MacBook Pro 16.

Due to the nature of the genre and its time of release, Psychonauts has an occasionally uncooperative camera, and there's a few minor bugs that may impede gameplay. Collectibles are also difficult to spot in brightly colored levels. Most of these issues are fixable by turning on VSync, playing in Windowed mode or tuning brightness levels. If that doesn't bother you, give this game - the finest JFK assassination simulator - a try. The milk is indeed delicious.

You need to get this game, you will not regret it!

150205868.review:
[h1] If I owned an original XBOX as a child, [b] I would've been all over this [/b] [/h1]

[i] yap session incoming. also my bad, this review is so late lmao. I've been meaning to write something after finishing the game two years ago [/i]

[h2] Prologue [/h2]
Before I begin, I would like to thank [b] James Willems [/b] for introducing me to this wonderful video-game. Thoroughly, I have enjoyed the gaming/entertainment videos that [b] Funhaus [/b] have created during their 2014-2021 era (and Machinima days) and have always had my 15y/o self echoing gut-wrenching laughs in times of comfort and from there, one of their members established an out-of-time bit that I was too young or too unfamiliar to recognise; a game called Psychonauts. This was wayyy before the sequel was announced and much like most of their fanbase, the jokes James would reference about Psychonauts would go over all our heads. 

I didn't think much of it until VGAs rolled around and I saw the twitter pic of Mr Willems' face most astonished and shocked face as he reacted to the news of the upcoming sequel. Then what followed were his replays on his personal channel with his wife and his audition to become its voice actors as a talking toilet. And from there my confusion turned into intrigue. Then just months before the sequel releases, I gave it a shot and bought it discounted.

Now 20 y/o at the time, my first impression of Psychonauts before playing was...ugly. Like I thought the artstyle was ugly, the characters = ugly, the colours = garishly ugly. Back then my close-minded ass wondered [i]"why would anyone willingly play a game so visually disturbing and gross looking  [/i]. But I eventually forgave its aesthetic simply of it being an early 2000's console game. I've heard so many great and insightful things about this game from Mr Willems that I marched forward expecting his proclamations to be true, pushing myself to start this journey and entered Summer camp with an open mind (see what i did there).

[h2] Story [/h2]

This is fairly non-spoiler. So as much as I would listen how much James Willems fawn over how much he love this game, I had zero idea or preconception of what this was about. Maybe I was subconsciously blocking out story details so I would play this game purely blind. I went into this game thinking I'm gonna have to constantly put up with its art-style and yucky mucky characters, that I'm gonna have to have this acidic feeling in my gut everytime I attempt to interact with the other characters...

...and then they spoke.

All this time, I had it so wrong. Why did I expect a game as visually unique function similarly to other indie games I've played. So I switched out my 'hardcore gaming brain' to my 'film major super analysis brain' and approached Psychonauts from an entirely new perspective. This game doesn't look gross... it's charming, and its fun, funny, funny-looking and doesn't take itself too seriously. The first cut-scene of Raz sneaking into Whispering Rock Summer Camp, catapulted my brain to remember all the times my kid self watched TV at home on a school day. 'Psychonauts' reminds me of those late 90's / early 2000's western serialised TV shows: Hey Arnold, Billy & Mandy, Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends, My Gym Partner's a Monkey, etc. I loooved watching these shows as a kid everytime they come on the American channel (I'm from Australia so there's like idk 2-3 American channels on cable at the time) and if I owned an original XBOX, I would've been all over Psychonauts, simply of how familiar its presence is and how similar the comedy is to other shows in the same era.

Then when the cutscene explains how this world consists of Psychics and Superpowers, has the child-like perception of what International Spy work is like (like Spy Kids and Spies Next Door), and there's a secret organisation teaching kids how to use their powers like X-Men and protecting themselves from other psychic animals which reminded me Gravity Falls, I was like "FUCK yeAH, I'm so on board with this concept, gimme more of thatl!"

And by the time the first mission came up, to infiltrate Coach Oleander's mind and battle his psyche and mental immune system in the form of little personified goblin guys, my jaw was floored and my mind (in-game and irl) was blown with how this game came up with the idea of Inception, years before Inception. And once my realisation set in, my eyes were GLUED to the screen for hours because of how invested I was to continue such a creative and freshly unique gaming and narrative experience (and this was only the first 10 minutes, wtfff what a way to lure me in, Double Fine).

Alright now to dive deeper into more spoiler-esque territory :)

[spoiler] 
I was enthralled with the idea of incepting into someone's mind and in the words of Agent Nein, [I] not fix their problems but help fight their inner demons [/i], opened up a lot of ways I perceived mental health and helped me understand that not all ways of thinking are black and white.
Also what better way to expand on the Inception concept than to have the subsequent missions take place in the minds of mental asylum patients, each so varying in personality, energy and uniqueness. My all-time favourite levels are Black Velvetopia, Waterloo World and the community standout, The Milkman Conspiracy.

Story-wise, the game did a great job executing a children's show-like mystery plot, interweaving elements of spies and superpowers to supplement a really well-written narrative. I love so many of the characters in this game, Dogen being one of my favourites as the air-headed animal abuser and each one so distinct; the wacky art-style grew on me and I found a newfound appreciation for it. I also appreciate the game for owning this whimsical art-style in the first place, which is essential in translating some of its internal mature themes of trauma, authoritative parental figures and self-image towards children, so that they understand it in a fun and interactive experience.

Calling back on Agent Nein's quote, there is no definitive bad-guy or overall antagonist, as much as the game would have me believe Dr Loboto was the main villain nor Coach Oleander; were effective villains to Razputin, I was glad that the final showdown consisted of Raz's confronting his inner demons, or his negative interpretation of his overly disapproving Father with unrealistic life expectations.
(Also I find it funny how when you want to run away from home, you join the circus and Raz ran from the circus to join the Psychonauts, thats a good one). 

Prior to all events, Razputin's fear of his perception of his father coincides with the common assumption most children have with overly invasive parents with high expectations of them. Not all people are cut & dry so I was overjoyed to discover his father was also a psychic and only wanted what was best for Raz, even open minded to learning his newfound powers as a way to bond father-to-son.
[/spoiler]

[h3] Gameplay [/h3]
As janky as console-ports go, this was surprisingly intuitive and became easy to get the hang of. The platforming reminds me of Ratchet & Clank which I enjoyed very much. Every Puzzle took me a while but super rewarding to complete.
Combat-wise: introduction of multiple psychic abilities allowed for multiple play-styles during battle engagements. As an avid gamer, it wasn't too challenging but I appreciate having different style enemies to force me to change up my loadout or play strategically than aggressively, which is why I loved using PsiBlast and Pyro to focus ranged attacks. 

TL;DR
This game is so underappreciated and if you can overlook how it looks and how it plays for its time, trust when I say this, you will be thoroughly entertained by the world of Psychonauts. There's so many things I wanted to say but as I just found out, damn Steam reviews have a character limitation, but for now I leave a 8.5/10 for such a rich and rewarding story experience.

Okay. Listen. If you know me, you know this is my FAVORITE GAME and I recommend it to EVERYONE. I have every achievement and I own this on 4 different platforms.

HESITANT but I'm recommending this anyway because I think everyone should play it. Just think twice before you buy it for PC.

147608962.review: I came into Psychonauts expecting a dated and janky mess whose charm carried it, but my expectations were blown away almost immediately. As someone who has only played 3D platformers from Nintendo, this game was a massive breath of fresh air. Yes, the platforming, humor, art style, and characters are one of a kind, but I loved how every person's backstory was told through their own unique settings. Every person's psyche had something vastly different to do, from rampaging through a fish-inhabited city to uncovering a conspiracy about a milkman in an impossibly structured neighborhood. For such a small game, it is jam-packed with ideas and every person and place has something unique to say. What I like most is how a person’s back story is presented, my favorite being in Milla Vodello’s psyche. You come across a slideshow of Milla taking care of an orphanage until it burns down as she is out shopping, leaving her haunted by the souls of the children she failed. That’s just the slideshow. Right next to it is a portal leading to a flaming jail cell where the dead children’s whispers take over all the sounds in the area. You don’t even have the option to help Milla get past this. It’s just something she keeps bottled up in an otherwise upbeat setting. I also really like that Raz is presented as the most reasonable person in the game, making everyone around him seem crazier than he is, but he’s revealed to have delusions that he can’t conquer on his own. It’s a great twist that puts our entire perspective into question. While I highly recommend this game, I don’t think it’s perfect. Most of its problems stem from its age. By the end of the game, the platforming can get janky, and checkpoint placements make this even more frustrating. The combat is good, but the lack of enemy variety makes it a bit tedious at times. The bosses, while really creative, also have some jank to them. The worst enemy in the game is the camera, which I found myself fighting quite a bit. Finally, it rubs me the wrong way that we cannot enter camp after the last few hours of the game, making much of what’s collected in those final hours virtually useless. All of these issues are pretty minor but they definitely show the game’s age. Overall, Psychonauts is one of the weirdest, funniest, and most creative games I have ever played. It’s shocking it took this long for a sequel to be made but I can see why this excited so many people last year. Now I am really looking forward to playing Psychonauts 2 and I’m curious about how the sequel evolved from its predecessor after 16 years.

147391780.review:
Narrativa Innovadora: La historia sigue a Raz, un joven aspirante a psiconauta, mientras explora las mentes de varios personajes coloridos. Esta premisa ofrece una variedad infinita de escenarios y desafíos, lo que convierte cada nivel en una experiencia única.

Personajes Inolvidables: "Psychonauts" está poblado por una serie de personajes inolvidables, cada uno con su propia personalidad y problemas. Estos personajes están tan bien escritos y desarrollados que te sentirás emocionalmente conectado con ellos, incluso en medio de la extravagancia del juego.

Diseño de Nivel Creativo: Cada nivel dentro del juego representa la psique de un personaje diferente y está diseñado de manera ingeniosa para reflejar sus miedos, deseos y personalidad. Los mundos son vívidos, creativos y visualmente impactantes, lo que hace que explorarlos sea una delicia.

Habilidad Psi-Poderes: Raz tiene habilidades psíquicas que utiliza para resolver rompecabezas, combatir enemigos y avanzar en el juego. Estos poderes incluyen telequinesis, control mental y levitación, y se utilizan de formas ingeniosas para crear una jugabilidad variada y desafiante.

Humor y Creatividad: "Psychonauts" es increíblemente divertido y tiene un sentido del humor único y surrealista. Las situaciones cómicas, los diálogos ingeniosos y los chistes inteligentes hacen que cada momento sea una delicia, manteniendo una sonrisa en tu rostro durante toda la aventura.

147234111.review:
[h1]Psychonauts[/h1]

[h3]Introduction[/h3]

Psychonauts is a 3D adventure game that pushes the limit of creativity in level design and character development.

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]

You control Razputin the up and coming Pyschonaut at brain camp. There is a ton of exploring the main hub of the campground and the levels themselves contain a lot of platforming sections that can be tedious at times but overall presents a great challenge.

In this play-through I used the steam deck controls which were very difficult to map as the controller had a spinning camera issue that took a while to fix. Once fixed the controls were great. Halfway through I switched to Mouse and keyboard and found that controlling the character this way took some getting used to. It allowed for an easier experience remapping the various psycho abilities on the fly.

[h3]Graphics and Visuals[/h3]

Graphics are an older OG XBOX era cartoon polish. The steam version is very sharp and feels and looks amazing. The cutscenes are not optimized however and the age of the game shows during these times.
I enjoyed the creative levels and the mix of bright and colorful with dark and gloomy and even cozy campground vibes.

No technical issues experienced in my time playing.

[h3]Storyline and Narrative[/h3]

The story is where the game shines. I was attracted to learning more about Razputins past and how the young Pyschonaut rises to Hero status. It was a heartwarming story that has humor and doesn't take itself too seriously.

[h3]Audio and Sound Design[/h3]

The soundtrack is superb, from the opening background music to each levels design, the themes blend together to truly make an immersive world to enjoy and explore.
The character voices are unique and the dedication of the voice actors to create varied and interesting characters shines.

Conclusion:
This is an amazing 3D adventure game that pushes the creative bounds of level design, story and charm.

[h1]Final Rating 10/10[/h1]

146108920.review:
I have collected every figment, smashed open all the emotional baggages, extracted the mental cobwebs, found all the  [spoiler]scavenger hunt items[/spoiler] and collected all the PSI Cards. Yet, the platforming is awful.


[h1]THE BAD[/h1]

The first thing that comes to mind are the damn poles. Razputin (the character you control) always gets stuck in the air when you try to climb a pole. Only after a few attempts he finally decides it's a good idea to go up instead of down.

In the first level, [spoiler]Coach Oleander's mind[/spoiler], there are 2 occasions where you can find a flag tied on a pole that needs to be risen. Unless you enable [spoiler]V-Sync[/spoiler] (which slows down the game overall) you cannot proceed. I was stuck for a good while because of an optional setting?

And also, the [spoiler]Levitation Ball[/spoiler] randomly disabling itself while I am [spoiler]rolling[/spoiler] was extremely annoying.

You can't focus on an enemy while you are on your [spoiler]Levitation Ball[/spoiler]? Why?

The trampolines taking 1-2 jumps before letting Razputin jump higher was an absolute nerve, especially in the moments where [spoiler]you needed to use them repeatedly in order to collect a specific figment[/spoiler]. (Looking at you [spoiler]stupid Bird figment[/spoiler])

There's also the Camera automatically adjusting itself when you move. And the setting to disable this doesn't even work. Looking for some Figment that might be placed above? Too bad. I want to show you the pavement instead. (Looking at you [spoiler]Black Velvetopia[/spoiler])

Still in [spoiler]Black Velvetopia[/spoiler], you can [spoiler]start that one fight WITHOUT owning the required PSI Power[/spoiler]! And when are you telling me that?

My biggest annoyance were the [spoiler]Censors[/spoiler] spawning every second, especially in [spoiler]Black Velvetopia[/spoiler]. You leave an alley, enter, and there they are again charging at you when they know that you always blast them anyways why do they even bother attacking you. Trying to figure out where the last figment was with them always popping up got quite boring after a while.

I also really disliked the sliding mechanic in the game. It is not specific for certain terrains, no. They just decided [spoiler]a terrain inclined by a certain degree will make you slide down[/spoiler] and called it a day. This one really made me angry at times. Especially around [spoiler]Sasha's Lab[/spoiler]. There's a certain area where you can't [spoiler]walk normally and the game forces you to slide down[/spoiler]. Annoying.

The game is also NOT playable with keyboard and mouse. Sensitivity set to max and moving the camera is still slow. I was able to play only with my controller, which is a shame.

The message warning you about the Point of no Return showing for 1 millisecond is a really bad take. The first time I had played this game (not counted in the hours) was I ever so annoyed. I had not yet collected every collectible and I dreaded playing the game from start. But guess what? The warning that showed for a millisecond actually reads [spoiler]"Automatically saving for Point of no Return" or something along these lines.[/spoiler]
 
[spoiler]There was an AutoSave placed before the cutscene[/spoiler]! And I found out about this 1 year later during this replay. Let me let you in on a little secret, [spoiler]show this warning BEFORE having us doing that specific action? And long enough for us to read it[/spoiler]? You will have a bad time playing this game for the first time ever. You have been warned.

And because I like you so much, I'll spoiler all the annoying things so you are able to experience them yourself.

[h1]Now the good things...[/h1]

Once the game grabs you, despite all its flaws, it's hard to abandon it. Surely if you only play it for the sake of completing every game you won't last long.

The camp is filled with various kind of characters, I liked how they interact with each other thorough the game. (Spoiler for achievements: [spoiler]and you can easily miss many achievements if you do not revisit previously explored areas after completing each level, specifically after finishing Sasha's and Milla's[/spoiler])

Collecting all the figments was PAIN; in every single level I always ended up missing only ONE figment, what a luck. I didn't use a guide, and when I got bored I just closed the game. Finding the last one in [spoiler]Milla's level[/spoiler] took me 3 days.

Currently trying to figure out what the secret achievement is.

145944146.review:
This game may be fun on other platforms, I wouldn't know since I haven't played much, but wow this port SUUUUUCKS. Here's why.

So I got this game mostly to play on my Steam Deck. Big mistake. The game has cloud saves, which is rare in games of this era, but the cloud saves don't work between Windows and Linux, so I was forced to use the Windows version of the game on my deck. So much for having a native Linux build when a core feature doesn't work on it. But that's just where the issues start.

For some reason, when using controller on my Deck with the Windows build, the control bindings completely fudged themselves. It showed keyboard icons on the menus, and ONLY accepted keyboard inputs. Even just to start the game required me to open the virtual keyboard. And even on my Windows PC, where this didn't happen, the options menu has NO CONTROLLER SUPPORT, and as far as I can tell that's not a bug. That's how the menus were designed. Wasn't this game on PS2? How could you NOT have full controller support?? That is impressively bad, even for the game's age. 

Not to mention, in basically any area that isn't the main gameplay, the mouse cursor is on screen. Even when using controller. It's not major but holy hell does it get annoying.

In general, I just can't recommend the game with all these issues. Sure, you CAN use keyboard and mouse, but it's VERY obvious the game wasn't designed with it in mind. Not to mention, that's not much an option on Steam Deck. I just wonder how the hell the game GOT so bad. Age isn't even an excuse; many games of the era have been updated with simple quality of life features and, hell, THIS game still gets maintenance updates. Could they not be bothered to just modify the game a bit to un-screw the controller input and fix cloud saves (which doesn't even require going into the game's code)? 

If this game got a facelift update to make it work in the modern day or, better yet, a remaster, I'd love to try the game out. It really didn't get a fair chance with this awful port. I'd be willing to give it leeway with its age, but seeing as it's being sold on a modern storefront for modern devices and there's no reason the game can't get quality of life updates, especially with renewed interest in the series, I think it's deserving of the not recommended review. Buy this game when it gets a remaster or a major update; until then, best stick to the PS2 version.

145939309.review:
I was really surprised by the high quality of Psychonauts. When I bought the game, I felt like I was just fulfilling a responsibility as I had heard it was a cult classic. It took me a long time to even start it up, since I figured it would have aged a ton. After only a short time with it, the experience still felt remarkably fresh. By the time it was over, I realized it had a lot of timeless aspects, but fills a great role even in the niche aspects of early platformers. 

The main appeal is that the game has so much personality, from its art to its jokes. As soon as I heard the protagonist, Raz, speak his first line, I knew I was in for a good time since I used to love Invader Zim and they both have the talent of Richard Horvitz. Most of the experience felt like I was playing through an old saturday morning cartoon, with all the adventure a kid would enjoy, but filled up with dozens of jokes an adult could sink their teeth into. Very few games are actually funny, especially as they get older, but this one seemed to work. I think it helped that it wasn't too long, and had a totally unique premise that was still easy to pick up fast. 

As a platforming game, I first thought it reminded me of stuff like Tak and the Power of Juju, likely because of its art and graphics; but then I felt like it was more similar to Glover on N64 with its numerous linear worlds. Eventually, it just had its own kind of level structure I couldn't make good comparisons with, it was original and fulfilling. Every new stage felt like a whole new take on the game, with very few frustrating segments. Despite the large amount of potential powers for the protagonist, they also made great use out of all of them. The only complaint I had is that the game is so linear and has so many unlockables that it felt like the most extended tutorial of all time. I don't think I stopped learning new things until I was 80% through. In some ways, it's also a collectathon; but I didn't dedicate much time to solving this puzzle, as I'm at an age where I don't find that 100% system all that fulfilling. I also think it's a little weaker than games like Banjo-Kazooie, since the collectables aren't very eye-catching. It didn't feel like 100 coins in Mario or all the bananas in DK64. It just felt like unfortunate filler to give more replayability to what is admittedly a pretty small game.

I'm not so sure if I'm quite ready for the sequel, but I still can see why this first game holds up as a major classic. There's so much to love even if you don't have any childhood nostalgia. They just don't make games like this anymore.

145837758.review:
There is so much I can say about this game, but I'll try to put it in short: 
This game is incredibly funny, really fun, and surprisingly thoughtful. The writer of the Portal series got his start in game writing here, while the main writer and director, Tim Schafer, had been making funny and character-focused games for over a decade. This game goes deep on its characters, with ten (or so) Mental Worlds packed to the brim with details that tell you about who they are, how they think, and what dark stories might exist in their memories.
And yet, it's not boring to play at all! It's actually got some awesome momentum mechanics under the hood that Sonic fans might find are pretty fun to play with. Look up a speedrun, it's incredible! 
Psychonauts is an absolute gem, and my best way to summarize it is:  It's an action-packed 3D platformer, made by point-and-click devs. The writing is amazing, and the gameplay mechanics are super fun to play around with. It might come across as clunky sometimes, but if you can get past that barrier, it's one of the most fun games of all time.

145399441.review:
In some ways, PsychoNauts can be so infuriating due to just how close it is to being a perfect video game. But that's the thing: It's so close to being a perfect game, that, if you're able to look past its few flaws, it can be exactly that.

An absolutely phenomenal 3D Platforming Collect-a-thon with just a few minor hiccups, most likely due to the fact that it was the developer's first shot at the genre.

With Point-and-Click DNA embedded within, there are some quite neat puzzles here that never get in the way of people who just want the platforming.

The story can be genuinely chilling, with some of the most hilarious writing I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing in a video game. This is a pretty damn solid port of the game, too, with my only real technical complaints being the jarring mouse movement in menus and stretching of the pre-rendered cutscenes. Even supported me importing DualShock controller prompts, which was very much appreciated.

The levels are all very unique, too.

I could ramble on for a lot longer on why I love this game, but to keep it short: This game is nearly flawless, and all of its triumphs far outweigh the few shortcomings.

Also Meat Circus is NOT as difficult as it's made out to be. It's pretty easy.

145336020.review:
A fun platformer, enjoyable combat and a excellent story with hilarious and unique characters all in one gaming experience.

That's how I would describe Psychonauts as short as possible.

If ya wanna hear more then keep reading:

Psychonauts is old to my understanding but I have always known about it. It didn't seem like that interesting of a game, it looked predictable and the style wasn't very appealing...
But then I played it... and I realised I'm a fucking dumbass. This is the best game I've played all year.

Never judge a book unless you've held it, read it, or have an ounce of understanding about it, that's what I learned from this game. 

It immediately introduces you to the world, shows you all the characters and powers at play, and during the course of the game it goes into greater depth while being entertaining and giving plenty of time for characters and events to explain themselves. 
The story itself is very cartoonish while having surreal moments and keeping a serious and almost horrific undertone. To be more simple, it has funny moments but serious (almost disturbing) moments melded together perfectly. 

And the pacing of the game is good. Each stage of the game gives you plenty of time to explore the map, before it gets boring, changing things up every time you complete a task, keeping you curious about what has changed and not disappointing you. If you see something that doesn't make sense, you probably missed it, now restart the game to see what happened. (JK, the game gives you plenty of save spots so you can always go back before you did something to either complete achievements or look around some more for interesting things)

Voice acting is just... PERFECT! I'm too lazy to say anything else.

Powers and abilities are fun and can be cycled through fairly easily. And not a single one is underutilised for the entirety of the game... I think.

The story itself is pretty good. Its aware all throughout, never forgetting anything that has happened. Also making use of every event that transpired before the previous.

Overall, I would recommend this game for nostalgia and a one of a kind experience. 

I love it. And so I will do something for it in the future...

Hopefully

Clunky, but worth it.  Having just played Psychonauts 2 and delving into the Doublefine documentary about it, I decided to revisit the first game and discovered I must have rage quit pretty early.

I will admit I SUCK at platforming, so this is the biggest hit against it for me.  It doesn't help that the camera is constantly auto-adjusting to a specific tilt angle if you are moving at all, even if it blocks your vision.  I rage quit a few times, but watched some playthroughs of tough areas just to get me past them.

But the good far outweighs the bad, the good being the creativity, design, characters, and dialogue.  There are SO MANY ideas packed into levels it's insane.  And while the sequel is definitely graphically superior, and probably more emotionally/mentally mature, it is definitely dwarfed by the first game in general wacky creativeness.  Also improved in the sequel is cheats for making platforming/constant dying easier!

144239619.review:
Surprisingly still playable on modern systems, solid 9/10 game.
If you want to play a classic, then this is a must-play.
The sequel gives you as recap of this game, so it's not required.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Basically every major issue with this game, the sequel handles a lot better and makes it not an issue.[list]
[*]Fights can be frustrating sometimes, especially when there's a lot of enemies at once.
[*]Hard to judge where you're going to land when it comes to swinging bars or tight ropes, the more you try to get good at them, the worse you're going to perform. The game is pretty forgiving when it comes to these if you just trust it.
[*]Two of your powers have limited charges, their ammo drops from the same sources as health, making it harder to heal.
[*]You have a limited number of "lives" that will kick you out of a level if you lose them all, this is never a problem because with any amount of skill you can keep yourself alive easily. But it is a strange design choice.[/list]

[h1]The Meat Circus[/h1]
If you've heard anything about Psychonauts, it's the infamous final level. Thankfully the Steam version is extremely nerfed in comparison to the original release, as they added many checkpoints where the original had none at all.

[h1]Achievements[/h1]
Lots and lots and lots of missable achievements, if you don't reference a checklist as you go through the game you're going to miss a lot.
It's not worth your time or effort to obtain them all, Pyschonauts 2 is a much more refined game and was more fun to 100% than this.

[h1]Graphics & Audio[/h1]
You're going to hear some audio popping, but nothing that will prevent you from playing.
The Doublefine intro is very loud regardless of how low you set the audio, I recommend taking your headphones off before booting up the game.

Graphics aren't too bad, only the cutscenes are noticeably low resolution because they're pre-rendered videos instead of real time.

144091999.review: Psychonauts is an incredibly inventive title that demonstrates how gameplay and narrative can work together seamlessly. Environmental storytelling is often taken for granted with games, but Psychonauts uses its imaginative levels to communicate stories that are in equal parts comedic and tragic. As a result, Double Fine delivers an artistic vision that could only be realized through the unique properties that come with video games. While the actual platforming and combat are a definite mixed bag, Psychonauts presents such a memorable experience that it's still easily one of the best 3D platformers of all time. Even with how dated some parts of it feel, the game is at the very least worth playing for its even more outstanding sequel.

142666218.review:
[h1]General [/h1] 

[b] Psychonauts[/b] is a mesmerizing journey that delves into the quirky, imaginative world of psychic spies known as Psychonauts. Step into the shoes of Raz, a young psychic prodigy, as he embarks on a surreal quest to [b]unravel the mysteries hidden within the human mind. [/b]

[h1] Pros and Cons [/h1]

+ Fantastical and creative universe filled with mind-bending landscapes and eccentric characters 
+ Each level is like a captivating tale, weaving together intriguing narratives that keep you hooked 
+ The game offers a plethora of psychic abilities that empower you to explore diverse pathways and find unique solutions to challenges.


+/- While the multitude of quests can be both engaging and varied, they may sometimes feel overwhelming due to their sheer quantity.
+/- There are many collectibles that depending on the player, can be annoying or fun 


- Due to the age of the game, control and camera views can be a bit wonky 
- Certain gameplay elements might feel slightly repetitive after extended play, but the charm of the world helps to compensate for this drawback.

[h1] Should you buy it? [/h1]

Of course!

If you're a fan of games like [b] "A Hat in Time" [/b] and [b]"Lost in Random," [/b]  you'll undoubtedly fall in love with the enchanting and surreal world of Psychonauts.

Remember, as you explore the depths of the psyche, beware of lurking dangers because not everything is what it seems.[b]Welcome to the world of Psychonauts, where the mind will be the ultimate playground. [/b]

142605834.review:
I am not the biggest fan of how psychonauts play. It is a bit clunky and platforming itself can be a bit annoying. Luckily the game gives you a double jump and slow falling option which makes the controls a bit more forgivable. By itself it is really not a hard game. Platofrming rarely presents a challenge, which in my opinion is good, since thee game is all about walking you through a story while enabling you to explore and collect some fun stuff.

A story focused platformer without the best platforming is not something that would usually get a pass, since the game needs to do something extraordinarily to compensate for the mediocre core mechanics. But Psychonauts manages to do something extraordinary. And I really didn't expect that.

What makes Psychonauts that great is art direction, character design, great voice acting and brilliant idea that is quite well executed. For the most part it felt like i was watching an intractable cartoon from the old Cartoon Network. Which felt amazing.

Every level is a new adventure with completely different vibe. And I got surprised and intrigued the more I played. Character design is also amazing. I don't remember seeing so much variety and personality in main and side characters in a videogame.

Even If I didn't like playing some of the levels, I can't praise enough how well the authors managed to convert mental problems into a visual and interactive experience. It is very hard to draw abstract concepts like love, paranoia, anger and fear. But Psychonauts manages to create entire mental worlds with graet visual hints and allegories.

My favorite levels are Milkman Conspiracy, Black Velvetopia and Waterloo World The levels that I didn't like that much were Lungfishopolis, Brain Tumbler Experiment, Gloria’s Theater and Meat Circus

The game, of course, had to simplify some of the mental problem concepts in order to make the experience understandable and digestible. I personally don't have a problem with that. But it would definitely be cool to see these mental worlds paint more multidimensional perspective on given troubles or circumstances that led character into such mental state.

With that said I recommend playing Psychonauts. Although the 3D platforming standards from 2005 should be noted. But if you can get past the clunky controls, a great adventure awaits you.

Short review:
 It is nowhere near the masterpiece everyone says it is. But it is a complete goldmine of creativity that is only really held back by its horrible camera and various movement bugs that completely fuck you over on multiple occasions.
 For 10 U.S dollars, I'd say this is a must-play for anyone who is a fan of 3D platformers (I am someone who very much finds the genre incredibly boring. Only enjoying a select few games. ) 

10 dollars for a roughly 10-hour experience with very little replay value is a bit of a bad deal to me, I can excuse it for the level design and concepts the game experiments with alone. 

But with all that being said, I quit the game after Waterloo World, the stale gameplay was just too overbearing for me to continue it any farther.

Overall, I guess I'd give it an 8/10. Great, but held back by some very glaring flaws.

For a personal review, I'd say a 5/10, the gameplay is very boring and gets tedious very fast, the interesting concepts and waterfall of creative genius can only carry this game so far for me.

Mental marines who are about to ship out on the adventure of their lives! This is our beachhead! And this is your landing craft. You shall engage the enemy in his own mentality--you shall chase his dreams, you shall fight his demons, you shall live his nightmares! The ending left a slightly rancid taste in my mouth – although the story I had no problem with – after already feeling slightly fatigued from playing so far.

It's a fine purchase at a sale price but I can't say that my instinct after finishing the game was to look into the sequel either.

141304856.review:
This was honestly one of the most creative and entertaining platformers I've ever played. The level design is so inspired and constantly keeping me looking forward to whatever's next. However, there are a couple levels that very suddenly disrupt the pacing of the game by being much less about platforming and more about solution-finding.

Beyond platforming, the world is shockingly lived in, and between levels the NPCs are always doing something new. If you wanted to, you can go and discover multiple side-stories happening at once with character design and delightful voice acting reminiscent of a Saturday morning cartoon. The main character himself is such a great avatar for the "go-getter" attitude of a platformer player.

In short, I have nostalgia for a game I played last year. I miss you, psychonauts.

This is one of the games where I'd rather appreciate from afar rather than actually playing it.

The art direction, personality and humor are amazing! However I can't say the same for the gameplay aka. the platforming and combat in this game.

The platforming is clunky and for some reason my sense of depth perception doesn't work in this game as Razputin's momentum and delayed jumps keep overshooting or undershooting the platforms. Furthermore, there are countless spots where Raz just "slide" when he's not supposed to.

Additionally, the camera sometimes just clips through walls/objects, just straight up preventing me from seeing what's going on.

140342184.review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- The game's age is really showing. I played through the entire thing with unmodified visuals, but I'd highly suggest going over to nexusmods and seeing what's available in terms of 4K textures and cutscene upscaling. Although the gameplay visuals clean up a bit when you raise the resolution, the cutscenes look super muddy and blurry
- The game's visual style is still pretty great, though. Very cartoonish. The character designs are very Tim Burton-esque
- The game's music is pretty good. It's about what you'd expect from a mid-00's platformer. Jaunty, cartoonish tunes abound
- The vocal performances are pretty good. I recognized some of the voices from other properties. Some characters do, unfortunately, sound pretty annoying (kids crying in games will always be grating to the ears)

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- This is where Psychonauts really excels. The story is excellent. In addition to the plot being engaging, the emotional and developmental narratives really do carry this coming-of-age tale along nicely
- The plot follows the story of a young boy named Razputin, who sneaks his way into a Psychonauts training summer camp in hopes of pursuing his chosen career. Unfortunately, your father, a circus performer who wants Raz to become an acrobat, catches wind and is on his way to pick you up from the camp. You're going to have to work fast to collect your Psychonaut skills before he shows up, especially when kids around the camp begin to mysteriously lose their brains
- The emotional content of the game does a nice job of highlighting the natural friction between aspiration and expectation; it asks some important questions. Should we choose to pursue or dreams, or take the most obvious path forward? Are we fair to those who stand in the way of our goals, or can we step outside ourselves to see the concern and love that can sometimes place obstacles in our path?
- In all, it's a more contemplative and interesting approach to the 3D platformer than you'll see from other similar games of the era

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- In addition to the game's summer camp overworld, you'll go from level to level by jumping into the minds of different characters. All of the levels have excellent and interesting design, making good use of vertical and horizontal space. It's nice that the path forward is almost always clear despite how densely packed most of the levels are
- As you may expect from a 3D platformer, you're going to do a lot of jumping around, exploring stages, picking up collectibles, fighting enemies, defeating bosses, and unlocking new abilities
- The platforming mechanics are fairly average; they don't feel overly snappy or sluggish. Like in many 3D platformers, the camera is a constant source of frustration. I've seen worse, but it's still annoying to make certain jumps when the camera is hiding Raz behind level architecture, forcing you to make jumps with weird camera perspectives
- The powers are pretty closely woven into the level design. I appreciate that the game is up-front about which powers and abilities you'll need for certain levels. Does completing a level require the Telekinesis ability? Well, the game will let you enter that level if you want, but it'll tell you that you won't be able to complete it
- Rather than powers being unlocked by beating bosses, you'll get them as you level up Raz throughout the game
- I'm not sure if I'll be replaying Psychonauts anytime soon, but it would be nice to come back and do some achievement cleanup down the road

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- I missed this one back when it was released. Halo 2 had just been come out and that's basically all I played at the time. It was nice to go back and finally experience what is widely considered a cult classic. I can see the appeal; there's more to Psychonauts than there is to most platformers
- Being an old game, you won't have much trouble getting this to run on most hardware. I have a fairly midrange setup, and it didn't break a sweat running this game

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
[b]8.5/10[/b]. It's been a well-regarded game for a long time for a reason. The narrative and gameplay still hold up in spite of the dated visuals (again, consider doing a little modding to fix that issue). If you're in the mood for a platformer, it's well worth considering this popular title

140330003.review:
[h1] One of the best 3D platformers ever made.  [/h1]

I'm a massive fan of platformers, both 2D and 3D. It was the main genre that made me interested in video games to begin with. Over the years, I've played a lot of them. From the simple pleasure of Mario, to the fast paced and inconsistent rollarcoaster of Sonic, to the smashing and bashing of Crash Bandicoot, I've seen all of the biggest stars of this genre. Psychonauts, meanwhile, is a game that easily deserves to stand among them. 

[b] In fact, I'd go so far to say that this game alone is better than most of them.  [/b]

Firstly, the story and writing is fantastic. The care and effort put into it is obvious at all times. If you're somehow unaware of the plot, I won't spoil it. It's a rather simple story honestly, but the characters are what make it great. The core premise of the game revolves around a young psychic kid named Razputin who has to use his powers to enter the minds of other characters. As such, every level is themed around that character's mind. Themed around their past. Themed around their trauma. Psychonauts is not a game to shy away from dark subject matter. Many of the minds you enter in this game belong to deeply troubled individuals suffering from mental illness, and your goal is to help them work through their trauma and help them forge better lives for themselves. It's all handled with such care and attention to detail. Every collectable you find has meaning beyond it's gameplay value. From figments of ideas that compliment their surroundings, to literal emotional baggage, to mental cobwebs formed by an individual neglecting part of their psyche, and to living vaults that contain the individuals brightest (and darkest) memories. Everything in this game is working to tell the story and flesh out it's characters.

However, despite it's very serious subject matter, Psychonauts is a delightfully funny game. The game is constantly hitting you with jokes, and not in an overbearing way either. Psychonauts knows exactly when to be funny and exactly when to be serious. It's not mocking it's subject matter. The humor serves to constantly lighten the mood and never allow the game to become overly dark. As for the type of humor in Psychonauts, it's usually dark humor, but portrayed in a very cartoony over-the-top way. It's pretty similar to something like Invader Zim or The Grim Adventures of Billy and Mandy, which seems appropriate considering the game's voice talent. It's very 2000s feeling, but in the best possible way. Thankfully, the writing actually aged pretty damn well in my opinion, which I unfortunately can't say for a lot of other 2000s comedy media.

But enough about story, what about the gameplay? Well, it's fantastic too. Some people call the game a collectathon which it kinda is but also kinda isn't. Every non-inventory item serves to boost your Psi-Cadet Rank. Collect enough of the right things, and you rank up. The maximum rank is 101, and that's essentially 100% completion. You only need to hit rank 30 (which is not at all hard to do) to beat the game. After you hit 30, you simply get helpful but unneeded upgrades. I got 101% which was (mostly) a pretty fun task. Most of the collectables are a blast to get, although figments can be pretty annoying. However it's still not accurate to call it an actual collectathon. Rather, Psychonauts is a level by level platformer with combat and old-school adventure game elements. Some levels lean hard on platforming, some lean hard on combat, and some lean hard on adventure-style puzzle solving. So let's break all three down one by one.

Platforming:
Razputin was born in the circus, so he's a very skilled acrobat. The game is filled with various circus-themed obstacles, alongside usual platforming obstacles. The controls are pretty smooth and it's pretty fun to just jump and fling yourself around. Raz is also a psychic, so he learns various psychic powers throughout the plot. Most of them don't have platforming use, aside from one notable exception: Levitation. Raz can summon a rolling ball and bounce high in the air then glide freely to the ground. It's kinda broken but it's super fun. There's not much more to say about platforming. It's pretty fun and it does it's job.

Combat:
The combat is alright. Raz has a three hit combo as well as various psychic moves you can pull out. It's pretty easy to exploit, especially if you have a pretty high rank, but again it's fun enough to keep the gameplay interesting. Enemies were pretty repetitive but it's not a big deal. Combat isn't really a big deal.

Adventure:
The game involves a lot of talking to characters, figuring out what they want you to do, and often what item you need to find to do it. The puzzles never get that complicated but it keeps the levels interesting. The game naturally also has lots and lots of exploration, especially if you want to go for 101%. 

While none of these three styles are super deep, the game is greater than the sum of it's parts. It all adds together into a really great gameplay loop, and when you add that with the constant deliberate story it all combines to a very complete feeling experience. The game is firing on all fronts, and even if it didn't hit the mark perfectly on all of them, it hit close enough that it doesn't really matter to me. Psychonauts is a cult classic for a reason, and I think everyone owes it to themselves to play it at least once. For the cheap price this game is constantly at, recommending this is a no-brainer.... TV?

139842451.review:
Я рекомендую игру, НО!
Oh, man... Psychonauts я закончила больше из упрямства и желания узнать сюжет самолично, в противном случае, я бы бросила ее ближе к концу, потому что примерно там она становится такой душной, что контроллер в какой-то момент может полететь в стенку.
Прекрасно понимаю, за что многие так любят эту игру - она невероятно обаятельная, сюжет и персонажи влюбляют в себя сразу, и в целом, как платформер-адвенчура игра смотрится весьма хорошо.

И насколько же в ней классный сюжет и персонажи, настолько же она уже устарела по своему геймплею.
Давайте посчитаем:
* Камера. Особенно камера на боссах. Она просто невозможная и неконтролируемая, не позволяет отвести взгляд от боссов ни на секунду, не позволяя оценить окружение. На платформинге она тоже периодически лочится самым неудобным образом, усложняя и без того сложную задачу навигации в игре.
* Сам платформинг - усложнен ради усложнения, Раз местами очень плохо притягивается к шестам, а глупая камера усложняет понимание недолет или перелет у тебя случается. Эпогей платформенной душности - это последняя локация, где у тебя условный "таймер" и очень смутное понимание куда вообще нужно двигаться
* Игра зачастую не соизволяет достаточно внятно разъяснить игроку, что вообще нафиг от него требуется. Да блин, я гуглила подсказки для прохождения боссов в этой игре чаще, чем гуглила что делать за всю point&click трилогию про Депонию. Причем это в первую очередь связано с тем, что у игры отвратительная индикация для интерактивных объектов, какую именно способность к ним можно применить. В итоге в среднем боссы достаточно простые, но если честно тратить время на то, чтобы разобраться, а что вообще с ними делать, ты можешь умереть много раз, потому что тебя будут постоянно прессовать атаками, не давая подумать, а камера - не давать оглядется.
* Если говорить о головоломках, то игра очень любит тратить время игрока местами, в такие моменты собственно больше напоминая квест, где ты вынужден бэктречить по часу в одной локации, чтобы наконец разобраться, что требуется.
* Последний уровень. Эпогей всех проблем игры. Он очень сложный, и он просто душно сложный. Местами, пройдешь ты или нет, зависит от везения и не дай бог ты серьезно проваливаешь платформинг (эскорт часть), все начинается заново. Вторая часть, с рельсами сложная просто потому что разработчики что-то нахимичили странное с тем, как Раз прыгает на рельсах и вылететь с трассы - как не фиг делать, и это совершенно не честный челлендж. А что касается последних боссов - я вообще не представляю, как именно девелоперы задумывали как игрок будет допирать сам до того, что нужно сделать, потому что я к этому моменту сдалась и просто смотрела вики. И даже ЗНАЯ что делать, это получалось сделать далеко не сразу из-за кривоты того, как работают некоторые механики. Это реально место, где твой геймпад или клавиатура просто тупо может полететь в стену, потому что становится абсурдно нечестно.

Этот отзыв положительный чисто потому что игра весьма старая, и за годы с ее выпуска очень много изменилось. Однако при попытке ее пройти, стоит ожидать, что местами она может катком проехаться по вашим нервам, но наверно, я могу сказать, что этого того стоило для меня ради истории самой по себе.

138978261.review:
[h1]Psychonauts: A Mind-Bending Adventure with Quirky Charm[/h1]

[h2]Imaginative and Colorful Visuals[/h2]
Psychonauts transports you into a world where imagination knows no bounds. The game features a vibrant and visually stunning art style that brings the bizarre and whimsical mental landscapes to life. Each level is a visual feast, filled with quirky characters, surreal environments, and mind-bending designs. The creative visuals add an extra layer of immersion and make every moment in Psychonauts a captivating visual experience.

[h2]Unforgettable Characters and Humor[/h2]
One of the standout features of Psychonauts is its unforgettable cast of characters. From the endearing protagonist Razputin "Raz" Aquato to the eccentric camp counselors and bizarre mental patients, each character is brimming with personality and charm. The game's witty dialogue and clever humor add a touch of levity to the adventure, making you chuckle and smile throughout your journey.

[h2]Mind-Bending Gameplay[/h2]
Prepare to dive into the minds of others in Psychonauts. As a young psychic prodigy, you'll explore the inner workings of people's minds, unraveling their deepest secrets and confronting their psychological challenges. The gameplay combines platforming, puzzle-solving, and psychic abilities, offering a unique and engaging experience. Each mind presents its own distinct challenges, filled with imaginative puzzles and clever level design.

[h2]Emotional and Captivating Storyline[/h2]
Psychonauts weaves a captivating and emotional storyline that touches upon themes of self-discovery, friendship, and personal growth. The narrative takes you on a journey through the minds of various characters, uncovering their fears, traumas, and hidden memories. The storytelling is masterfully executed, balancing heartfelt moments with lighthearted humor. As you delve deeper into the story, you'll become invested in the lives of the characters and their struggles.

[h2]Quirky Soundtrack[/h2]
The soundtrack of Psychonauts perfectly complements the game's offbeat and whimsical atmosphere. The music ranges from catchy and upbeat tunes to haunting melodies, creating a unique auditory experience. The eclectic mix of genres and styles adds depth to the game world and enhances the overall immersion.

[h2]Memorable and Varied Levels[/h2]
Psychonauts delights with its diverse and memorable levels. Each mental landscape you explore is a new adventure, filled with surprises and challenges. Whether you're navigating through a twisted circus, exploring a psychedelic party, or traversing a twisted subconscious, the levels offer a fresh and exciting experience that keeps you engaged from start to finish.

In summary, Psychonauts is a mind-bending adventure that combines imaginative visuals, unforgettable characters, and a captivating storyline. With its unique gameplay, clever humor, and whimsical charm, the game offers an experience like no other. Whether you're a fan of platformers, puzzle-solving, or simply appreciate games with heart and creativity, Psychonauts is a must-play title that will leave a lasting impression on your mind and heart.

138847957.review:
Psychonauts is a platformer game with elements of puzzle and combat. You play as a boy named Raz, attending a summer camp to develop his psychic abilities and become a Psychonaut, secret agents who can traverse the minds of others. But when the fellow campers and the mentors start losing their brains, Raz might just have the chance to prove that he got what it takes. The game has a really unique artstyle, with very stylized, cartoony, caricature-like characters. But it fits the overall comedic tone.

What I really like about this game is the variation of levels and mechanics when we enter someone's mind. Some levels, especially the early ones, can be linear and straightforward, getting from start to finish under guidance from the mentors. In later levels, some are more open and less linear, making you do a set of objectives to progress. And the settings are vastly different as well. Like you have a disco club level which serves as Levitation training, a fish city where you're a giant, a twisting neighborhood filled with suspicious characters, and more. It's guaranteed you'll never get bored!

Combat is also pretty creative, and not just throwing punches. Your psychic abilities will be a great help, and sometimes even being the sole way to deal with enemies or bosses, yet they are used for exploration as well. Like you have telekinesis, pyrokinesis, shield, and invisibility among others. And there are lots of enemy types, looking distinct from each other and having different powers, much like the mind-worlds they appear in.

I think Psychonauts is a surprisingly ambitious game, having great variations in levels and enemies, as well as being quite longer than expected, yet not overstaying its welcome. If you like 3D platformers with action such as American McGee's Alice or A Hat in Time, you'll definitely have fun with this title. I got it for free from a HumbleBundle giveaway, but free or not it's worth your time and money.

A platformer where you use a psychedelic portal to enter the minds of mostly-willing subjects.

I recommend it wholeheartedly.

Thumbs up to the sky to this game.

Suffice it to say that I had previously owned Psychonauts since 2012 or so and never barely played it, only to pick it up back in April 2023 and not play any other game until I completed it 100%. 

Holds up surprisingly well for a game this old. Janky platforming and outdated graphics are severely outshined by a fantastic plot (centered on serious topics but told in a very funny way), the sheer charisma of every main character and, above all the rest, the innovative and well-crafted levels. 

Pick it up, it must be pretty cheap nowadays and it's a trip totally worth experiencing. A true hidden gem.

137489011.review:
I'm playing this as a companion piece to watching psychodyssey:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kRlI72bsNRc&list=PLIhLvue17Sd70y34zh2erWWpMyOnh4UN_

I can immediately see why this game is a cult classic, it's funny, it's imaginative, it's got about 3 times more content in it than you imagined it would have. I genuinely thought I was fighting the final boss of the game in 4 different occasions, only to be presented with yet another even more final boss shortly after.  

It's aged really well visually due to it's confident art direction, it's like being in an even more fucked up Tim Burton film, which I'm sure some people will not like, but fuck'em, it's really good. That being said, I would argue that it's only aged gracefully in the art & writing department, not so much in the mechanics of the game. I experienced a ton of frustration while playing for various reasons:

- Being gated from progression by meaningless tasks to collect about 800 shrute bucks or whatever random currency they use here
- Very finnicky platforming, retrying some jumps. 
- Shoe-horned in combat
- The lives system just feels outdated at this point, but I also freely admit I suck at platformers.

I also played this through on the steamdeck, which was not an effortless flawless experience, I had to keep rebinding keys as they showed up, but that turned up to not be too much of an issue once I crossed the halfway mark of the game and no new keys were added. 

Overall, I do recommend this game if you're into platformers or Double Fine's writing, but I would say that it's going to take some determination and commitment to finish this.

If you haven't played this game when you were younger, I highly recommend you do this before playing the sequel. Psychonauts doesn't have the tightest of controls, and sometimes the platforming will frustrate you, but this game has the most personality I've ever seen from a video game. It's funny, engaging, and just plain weird in all the best ways. It definitely feels dated, whether that's in the cutscenes rendered in like 10p or like how you can miss achievements in ways that don't really happen in modern games, but I'd play it today just as much as when it first released. If you like collectathons and stick around for the cutscenes, I'd highly recommend playing this game.

Oh, and get a guide if you're trying to get all the figments. Seriously. You will be stuck on one and it'll take you an hour just to find one figment.

135527199.review:
Psychonauts is so wonderfully odd. Despite initially being an underselling game in the mid 2000s, it eventually gained cult status and critical acclaim as one of the hidden gems of the 6th generation. 

To begin, I don’t think I’ve ever seen such a likable cast of characters in a 3D platformer before. Each character feels nuanced and unique, with likable, while flawed, personalities. Psychonauts is so cerebral, so unlike anything else I’ve played, that I don’t know why no one else has taken notes from everything Double Fine is doing so right. Since the whole idea of the story revolves around brains, psykinetic powers and the like, the game has the freedom to basically put whatever the hell insane ideas they want in each mind you explore. 

The story is the clear standout, pairing incredible character writing with some of the best comedy I’ve seen in games. Even after the recent 2010s surge of comedy driven games like The Stanley Parable and Henry Stickmin Collection, Psychonauts stands toe to toe with their comedic chops without using any sort of “meta” crutch AND still maintaining a genuinely fun gameplay style. 

The atmosphere is also top notch, so many areas are still etched into my mind, from the Milkman’s mind to that little room in the camp store with the TV in it, each area feels so humanly crafted, so personal. This is a perfect example of why people say that mainstream games don’t have the soul that they used to. I don’t really agree with that point but when this much raw charm is exuded by a game almost 18 years old, I can see why people think this type of game is dead now. (in my opinion these types of games have shifted more to the indie landscape) Anyway, this is a long-winded way of saying that I felt very comfortable in these environments, they felt homely and intimate oddly. It really endeared me to the world and helped me to take my time with each mind. 

As for the gameplay loop, you’re provided with a fair few interesting and engaging mechanics that slot quite plainly into the solutions for a good number of puzzles. The abilities are good fun, the balancing ball completely breaks the game in half and I love it. I’m fine with the ball because the platforming will often leave something to be desired. There are certainly some portions of the game that were near infuriating due to its’ jank, but the aforementioned ball was helpful in allowing some cheesy strats. 

Overall Psychonauts is an exceedingly underrated experience and one I’m so glad I finally decided to crack into. Its’ cerebral storytelling, strong characters, snappy and hilarious writing and captivating level design make it a certified cream of the crop platformer that I would recommend to pretty much anyone with a sense of humor.

135064689.review:
This is best described as beautifully infuriating. Highly recommended, but don't let the "cartoonish" look fool you, this is a challenging 3rd person platformer. 

Get the bad out of the way-Infuriating in that the game does not hold your hand. It does tell you what your next objective is, and sometmes gives a hint with a cutscene, but otherwise it is left to you to figure out how to achieve certain things. The platforming is tricking and being third person it can get tricky trying to land your mark, especially in later levels. There are some abilities you get that can help you out with transversal (one in particular), but it in itself is tricky to master. The save system is decent, though sometimes I found saving a game and then reloading put me further back. It does autosave in spots, but sometimes those spots are few and far between. I will admit looking up hints for how to progress.

The beautiful-such a visual feast. Each level is laid out with different ways and layouts to progress, and very much fun when the 3 dimesions start getting twisted around looking something out of escher. Because the story focusses on different peoples minds, the developers really have fun with this for the most part-later levels (particularly final ones) tend to be....not as well done IMO. But the beauty and fun of each level is worth transversing in itself (a certain level early in the game has an incredible Disco/70's theme that is beautiful just for the fun and the music alone, and the ability you get). Speaking of soundtrack, some great tunes and well done. Writing and dialogue is pretty good, and gets into some interesting ideas and themes about mental states, how people deal with their inner demons, and just a really thoughtful story about the dark side of mental illness. 

8/10 recommend. Its about 10=15 hours in length, so not the longest game, but the game really fits that time amount well.

135007819.review:
I'm trying to run this on an M1 mac and am, unfortunately, having way too many technical issues for me to be able to recommend it. There are many things that just don't populate for me such as the mines in a minefield have to navigate at one point, just leaving you to guess where or not they are, or the tacks you're supposed to hurt the big fish boss with not actually appearing to fling at him after hitting the boxes with the tacks in it and therefore not being able to tell that that's actually how you hurt him. I found that there are also just so many textures bleeding into each other in certain areas that they're incredibly difficult to navigate. Occasionally I ran into some near gamebreaking slowdown, too.

I think this is a really great game, and put a few hours into trying to get through it but there have just been way too many technical issues for me to keep pushing through to complete it, which is a disappointment because I really loved the world, storytelling and characters in it. I just think the game is a bit too much of a mess for people trying to run it on M1 macs to even have it available for purchase.

That said, love Double Fine, love the games they make - - this was just an unfortunate, frustrating experience for me <3

Psychonauts is a classic platform-adventure game that takes you on a psychic odyssey through the minds of misfits, monsters, and madmen. Developed by Double Fine Productions and released in 2005, Psychonauts has been praised for its originality, humor, and creativity.
The game follows Razputin "Raz" Aquato, a young psychic who runs away from the circus to join the Psychonauts, an elite group of international psychic secret agents. However, he soon discovers that something is wrong at their secret training facility: Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp. A mysterious villain has kidnapped Raz's fellow campers and stolen their brains. Now Raz must use his psychic powers of Telekinesis, Levitation, Invisibility, Pyrokinesis, and more to explore the fantastic realm of the inner mind and save the day.
Psychonauts is a game that will challenge your imagination and your skills. Each level is a unique mental world that reflects the personality and psyche of its owner. You will encounter giant lungfishes, rampaging milkmen, twisted dentists, disco dancers, meat circuses, and more. You will also collect figments of imagination, sort emotional baggage, unlock hidden memories, and fight mental demons along the way.
Overall, Psychonauts is a masterpiece of game design that deserves to be played by anyone who loves video games. It is a rare example of a game that combines gameplay innovation with storytelling excellence. It is funny, smart, charming, and unforgettable.
Psychonauts gets a 6/10.

134508273.review:
For those unfamiliar, Psychonauts is a 3D collect-a-thon platformer with DNA from older point and click adventure games.
With that out of the way, I am completely in love with this game! I would say it's my favorite game! The story, the humor, the art style, the music, the levels, the voice acting, it's all amazing! I've 100% completed this game 7 times, going on 8, and I'm still always finding new little details, it's jam packed with things to discover. 
The levels are all different from each other, enough I would say there's something here for everyone, but it still somehow feels cohesive. There's many big names in the voice cast, including Tara Strong and Richard Steven Horvitz, and even the smaller name voice actors do an incredible job! The art style, both with the 3D stuff like the gameplay and the cut-scenes, and the 2D stuff like the memory vaults, are very nice and have aged very well (though the character design may take some getting used to). 
The music in Psychonauts is fantastic, to the point where I showed a friend who doesn't usually take game suggestions a few of the songs and he decided to buy the game because of them! Peter McConnell is the composer for this game and he did great work!
Now onto the cons: The controls may take some getting used to, many find it to be a bit difficult to space some of the jumps, but hey! People who don't have depth perception like myself will have the same challenges as everyone else! 
If you use the subtitles, they take up a very large portion of the screen, and will cover up parts of the cut-scenes. 
One type of collectable, called figments, can be incredibly difficult to see at times. 
The humor can get a bit dark at times but if you're okay with that then you should certainly check it out!
Also if you enjoy the game there's a mini documentary by the developers you might be interested in checking out!

133788140.review:
Psychonauts is a highly acclaimed video game that combines an imaginative storyline with fun gameplay mechanics to create a truly unique gaming experience. The game is praised for its clever level design, engaging characters, and quirky sense of humor.

Players take on the role of Raz, a young psychic who joins a group of fellow psychonauts to explore the inner workings of the human mind. As Raz journeys through various mental landscapes, he must use his psychic abilities to solve puzzles and defeat enemies.

One of the strengths of Psychonauts is its ability to tackle serious issues such as mental illness and emotional trauma while maintaining a lighthearted tone. The game's colorful graphics and whimsical characters make it an enjoyable experience for players of all ages.

Overall, Psychonauts is a must-play game for fans of platformers and adventure games. Its memorable characters, creative storyline, and challenging gameplay make it a standout title in the gaming world.

133201064.review:
RECOMIENDO ESTE JUEGO: ¡Si!!!  y mucho 
(Sobre todo si te gustan los plataformeros 3D con uno que otro puzle y un estilo artístico "peculiar"). 
Dura entre 6-10 Horas (Yo tarde +40 para conseguir el 101%, los logros y recorrer cada rincón... varias veces... porque me perdía).
Los requerimientos para jugar son muy bajos (que corre en una tostadora pues...)

¿PORQUE LO RECOMIENDO?: 
El juego es divertido, las mecánicas son buenas y la historia es interesante.
Es del 2006 pero se ve bien, el apartado artístico es muy particular pero original el problema es en las cinemáticas porque les falta resolución.
Lo termine la primera vez en 3 o 4 sesiones, me tenía atrapado y no quería parar (después del final me agrado poder regresar a conseguir lo demás).

HISTORIA (de Wikipedia):
El protagonista de este videojuego es Raz, un muchacho que se cuela en un campamento veraniego para entrenamiento mental de los Psychonauts. Una vez allí descubrirá un misterioso complot para apoderarse de los cerebros de los alumnos y crear un ejército. 
El juego plantea retos de plataforma clásicos, como saltos imposibles, balanceos en cuerdas y barras, entre otros. 
La aventura está compuesta por trece escenarios donde Raz va descubriendo sus poderes mentales. 
El jugador también puede proyectarse dentro de los cerebros de otros personajes, donde deberá que superar diversos retos. Todos los cerebros son diferentes, cada uno de ellos refleja la personalidad de su dueño

COMENTARIOS:
Aunque el juego no tiene traducción oficial hay una completa en http://academia.clandlan.net/index.php?page=academia/view&id=283

Procura hacer guardados después de las misiones "importantes" de los maestros para que puedas regresar por unos logros que se pueden volver imposibles de conseguir si avanzas mucho.

Antes del final hay un punto de "no retorno" (con una tortuga involucrada), una vez pasado el punto ya no podrás regresar a hacer ciertas cosas o a comprar lo que te falte, procura tener un guardado antes y antes de llegar a este punto, haz todo lo que te falte.

+ Si se pone la pantalla negra (se va el video, pero si se escucha), sal de la aplicación (Alt+TAB) y vuelve a entrar hasta que se pueda a jugar correctamente, el juego se pausara automáticamente.

+ El menú en las opciones de configuración solo puede manejarse con el ratón-mouse.

133116688.review:
I've heard great things about Psychonauts. Don't take it from me, look at the Overwhelmingly Positive Steam reviews. After finally playing it myself in the year 2023, I respectfully disagree.

There's a lot to love, and I understand where people are coming from. The classic Double Fine style is on full display, and it looks great for its time. The world is imaginative and funny, and the characters are incredibly wacky. I fully enjoyed many parts of this game (Lungfish, Milkman, Napoleon).

However.

For such a story-focused game, it fails to bring a sense of cohesion to the table. Almost all the characters are extremely simple. Character introductions are sparse, if present at all. At many points, it feels like important plot beats are skipped. The penultimate area's denizens are given zero context before you're thrust into their heads, and they ultimately don't matter at all. It's all just so simple, and I was expecting more from such an esteemed classic.

Side note about the audiovisuals: the mixing is completely broken in this port. There's no way it was this bad on release, right? It contributed to me almost dropping the game.

Moving on to the gameplay: it's ass. The physics are jank, so much so that they are nearly broken in some places. The animations don't help, with how jerky they are. Its adventure game trappings make you go into your inventory and use a specific item in a specific place, which is wild to me in the year 2023, but I remember those days. It's ostensibly a platformer, but only, like, 3 or 4 levels make you use your fancy platforming moves. And don't get me started on the double jump. The game doesn't let you double jump all the time, but you can always float, which was extremely upsetting in the final level where a double jump would have done the same thing as the float in getting me to a platform, but the double jump was not allowed. Like I said before, it's jank.

Again, I liked parts of this game, and I appreciate it. But I can't recommend playing it yourself. I've heard good things about the sequel, so I hope that it's being held to higher standards than this.

133111998.review:
One of the standout features of Psychonauts is its creative and imaginative world design. The game takes place inside the minds of various characters, each with their own unique and surreal environments. The art style is whimsical and charming, with a lot of attention paid to small details that make the world feel alive.

The gameplay is equally impressive for its time as a 2005 game, with a mix of platforming, puzzle-solving, and combat that keeps the game feeling fresh throughout. The psychic abilities that Raz possesses allow for a lot of creative gameplay mechanics, such as levitation, pyrokinesis, and telekinesis, which all have their own unique uses.

One downside of the game is that the camera can be a bit finicky at times, especially during some of the more complex platforming sections.

133102370.review: Psychonauts is a game that will take you on a wild and trippy journey through the minds of its diverse cast of characters. The story and world-building are top-notch, with the game's unique sense of humor shining through in its dialogue and wacky scenarios. However, be warned: the gameplay can be more frustrating than trying to fit a square peg into a round hole, with bad camera angles and punishing level design. And while the design may feel dated by today's standards, it's still worth a play if you can tolerate the occasional controller-throwing tantrum. Or, if you'd rather not risk damaging your gaming equipment, you can always watch a Let's Play of the game and let someone else do the heavy lifting (and cursing).
