132874634.review:
Ah, Psychonauts! A charming and delightful game that blends platforming and action with a quirky sense of humor and a richly imagined world.

At its core, Psychonauts tells the story of Razputin, a young psychic with dreams of becoming a member of the eponymous Psychonauts - a group of elite agents who use their psychic powers to explore the inner workings of the mind. The game takes place in a summer camp for psychics, where Razputin must use his powers to navigate a series of mind-bending levels and uncover a sinister conspiracy that threatens not only the camp but the world at large.

The gameplay is a joy, with a mix of acrobatic platforming and psychic abilities that allow Razputin to interact with the world in unique and inventive ways. From levitation to telekinesis to pyrokinesis, each ability is fun and satisfying to use, and the levels are designed in such a way that players must use their powers in creative and clever ways to progress.

But perhaps what sets Psychonauts apart is its wit and charm. The game is filled with memorable characters, each with their own distinct personality and quirks, and the writing is clever and frequently hilarious. From the camp counselor who's secretly in love with his own brain to the milkman who's convinced that everyone is out to get him, the characters in Psychonauts are a delight to interact with and make the game's world feel all the more vibrant and alive.

In conclusion, Psychonauts is a must-play for anyone who loves inventive and imaginative games with a strong sense of humor. Its combination of clever writing, fun gameplay, and a richly imagined world make it a classic of the genre, and it's not hard to see why it's still beloved by fans today.

132660583.review:
Before you yell at me, I rate the gameplay itself, not the story, as the story is nice (But the whole package of the game itself isn't).

I had no real fun with this game in the slightest. 12 hours of pain in various places that I simply can't ignore. This imo only shows how much Psychonauts 2 improved on everything this game did wrong, but let's get to the main points I honestly dislike (Spoilers for the final parts of the game are included!).

[h1]Controls[/h1]
Controls are really bad. When using Keyboard and Mouse, the default settings have a really slow movement of the mouse itself, which doesn't change much when setting sensitivity to highest possible.

Controller is a bit better in that regard but still feels kinda weird. Not to mention are the actual settings like keyboard/controller bindings not accessible with the controller itself. Also, unplugging the controller while the game is running will make the cursor go absolutely nuts.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Gameplay is... okay. I'm not the biggest fan of having your PSI-Blast depend on a resource (Which thankfully was replaced with recharges in the 2nd game), the confusion granate is really only useful for one part (The one where you actually get it), invisibility has barely any real use and the platforming is often just awful.

Getting on a ledge, only to then have Razputin let go instead of climbing up happens a lot. The bars where he swings on also take ages for him to get to speed (Which in the final level - the Meat Circus - is also not good because of the "time limit" you have). and it just feels half-assed at times.

I also had the game crash on me at 3 different times without any provocation. I only entered a loading zone and that was it...

[h1]Meat Circus[/h1]
This entire level is pain. It's no fun from start to finish. You have to protect this little child, which on its own is interesting and challenging, but then you have to go through annoying platforming that also contains enemies you have to wait for them throwing stuff so you can progress... All while this annoying little kid gets hurt because he doesn't even think of running away.
I died so many times in that level because the little kid wanted to become a punching bag.

The Boss in form of the Butcher, Raz' father and then the combination of both is also annoying.
[list]
[*] The Butcher has hard to read attacks (Or at least very fast ones you barely have time to react on) And unless Ford tells you what to do (or you look up a walkthrough), it's not clear that you have to hit his head instead of his body.
[*] The opstacle course is absolute pain too, partially due to the aforementioned bad controls.
[*] The mix is actually okay... But only because you can actually punsh the shit out of the monster while being big and otherwise just have to keep your distance...
[/list]

[h1]Final words and suggestions[/h1]
If Double Fine is ever making a remake of this game, please consider these suggestions:
[list]
[*] Make the controls more like the second game as that one had really great ones imo
[*] Update the graphics (Obviously)
[*] Either improve the Meat circus or get rids of parts for it. Having to defend this little Brat while you first have to get to it through annoying platform was no fun... Make the boss actually more clear in terms of WHERE you have to damage it.
[*] Make the finding of psytanium (Deeply buried arrow heads) easier. It was an absolute pain and I'm not a fan of button mashing the shit out of my controler.
[/list]

132441664.review:
Perfect. Simply perfect game in absolutely every way:
The plot is childly simple but with a sprinkle of grownup psycho-analysis (which is done in the very right amount, meaning its not too serious and just enough childish)
The characters are amazing and their dialogues are hilarious.
Razputin is the best.
The gameplay is terrific, it varies from mind to mind, and while it has the core "if you can't shoot it, jump on it (and vice versa)" it really tries not to be repetitive and the game is good at it.
The level design is another huge topic I'd looooove to talk about but short review is -- its genius. Each mind level is very unique with a lot of small details that you will probably miss on your first walkthrough but will definitely notice on the second (like I did). Some details were funny, some were very disturbing, some even were crippy.
The music is also really nice and it suits the gameplay and helps the overall atmosphere.
The boss fights are superb and all the psychiatric thing about them, about the levels and the characters inside works really well all together, making the absolutely terrific atmosphere and feeling that you are not just walking through the minds, but curing them, figuring out what's wrong. It's kind of unique feature about this game. To defeat an enemy is one thing, but to help them overgrowth their issues instead is really other, much more rewarding.

I love this game, its amazing solid 10/10

132233546.review:
I have complaints as usual, however, I admire the effort and passion that went into this game. It might be nostalgia for these old-school games speaking but it hits all the right spots for me. The story is kept simple yet engaging which is commended by the world-building. Each character has a unique personality, the main characters especially shine due to their fleshed-out character dept. The gameplay is unarguably the highlight due to the creative level designs. The concept of entering the minds of other characters allows for a vast variety of level themes, each with a special quirk to it. It felt reminiscent of those dream levels in Spongebob BFBB, only in a bigger scope. What elevates the entering-characters-minds concept in this game is the whole psychological aspect of it. The developers knew precisely what they were doing with the characters and how they wanted to portray them through the different tones in each level. It blends excellently with the story and adds more layers to the characters. Even the humor they go for in this game occasionally got a chuckle out of me. They actually sneaked a Hitler reference into it which had me genuinely baffled the first time I heard it. Something notable in my book is also the voice acting. Not only is it outstanding, but the main character is voiced by Richard Horvitz. Most known for voicing Zim from Invader Zim.

Let's go over some negatives. Certain collectibles, like the Figments, are an absolute pain to gather. Not only is it nearly impossible to rely on a guide since there are too many of them in each level, but they are also difficult to spot due to being transparent. I must have dedicated a couple of hours trying to find one final figment in several levels because of that. Then there is the awful decision of having a point-of-no-return in the game. Because of that, a lot of achievements are indeed missable and you will most likely be forced to start a new game to acquire them. Thankfully, one of them could be cheesed by editing the save file to regain an item in your inventory, otherwise, I would have to replay the entire game again. It goes to show you to what extent people are willing to go because of a dreadful decision on the developer's part. I also have to question whether certain segments in this game were playtested. The final level is especially atrocious. It was only thanks to a generous checkpoint feature that I was able to eventually pass it.

Despite that, I'm overwhelmingly satisfied with the game as a whole. I'm certainly looking forward to playing the sequel. I do wish more games like this would take the spotlight in our modern day and age. It takes me back to the good old times when I could sit down and remain hooked to a screen for an entire day without a care in the world.

132219715.review:
Whoa! This game is fantastic! I mean, I thought it'd be good, but I wasn't expecting to enjoy it quite [i] this [/i] much.

Psychonauts is a really fun 3D platformer about psychics who borderline physically enter each other's minds to either sabotage or heal them. Of course, Raz (the character you play as) only ever heals them... y'know, cuz he's the hero--but I assume that if a psychonaut so desired, they could sabotage a mind. Anyway, the story sends Raz on a wacky and surprisingly grim adventure with plenty of opportunities for him to enter minds and sort out longstanding emotional traumas. It's pretty fascinating stuff, and is generally quite fun gameplay-wise too. The levels (aka the minds he enters) all vary wildly, which makes the game nice and diverse, but also gives ample opportunity for one or two to not be much to your liking, while others very much [i] are [/i] to your liking. That's how it happened with me anyway--for example, I love the Napoleon level with it's board game references and faux free roaming atmosphere, but the level right after it--the bull level--was a bit too murky and linear for my tastes. Both levels are perfectly fine conceptually, it's just that one happened to appeal way more to me than the other (although both did commit the sin of hiding a few of their collectibles in unfair places--seriously, what the HECK, Napoleon level???). Now, I [i] would [/i] say that because of this, there's likely to be something here for everyone, except that there aren't really enough levels for that in general. So instead I'll say that if you like the core concept of entering people's minds to work out their traumas from the inside (or if you just like 3D platformers), [i] then [/i] you should consider this game. Because I think that's the most interesting thing delivered here. And it's delivered in quite a nice way, too... an absurd, highly creative visual style, robust voice acting (Richard Horvitz, the voice of Invader Zim and Moxxie, as Raz!), and a great cast of incredibly vibrant characters. Honestly, as hype as it is to have Horvitz in the game, a lot of the other voice performances really steal the show--Boyd the paranoid conspiracy theorist, Crispin Whytehead the... just plain creep, Vernon the droning storyteller, Fred Bonaparte the unenthusiastic descendant of Napoleon... they may not be the most main or important characters, by my god any opportunity they get to open their mouths is golden. There's so much personality packed into this game that it's a wonder it doesn't burst out of the screen and ooze onto the floor.

That being said, I feel like this game doesn't take the story quite as far as it could. Although great on the whole, it never got me quite so invested that I felt like there was any truly impactful climax. I think this is probably because Raz and all the other main characters are... kind of boring. It honestly feels like, for some reason, less creativity was put into them than was put into some of the side characters. Raz in particular is, well... he kinda has main character syndrome. I don't see much in him beyond a generic do-gooder hero. But, on the whole, none of this bothers me very much, because there's still so much fun romping to be had even if there's nothing to get deeply attached to. And anyway there [i] is [/i] some deeply [i] interesting [/i] stuff, it's just not per se the main focus.

Also have I mentioned just how fun the gameplay is? It's got solid 3D platforming for one thing, and I love 3D platformers (it's my favorite genre, in fact), so there's that. But there's also all the cool psychic abilities you unlock slowly over the course of the game. [i] And [/i] several different types of collectibles to go for?? Count me in! ...Sadly they do get pretty grindy and unfun if you try to get all of them, buuuuut y'know, they're fine if you approach them casually.

I feel like I'm trailing off awkwardly with this review. How about a quick summary? This game is great! Very fun to play, very interesting story, and some of the best voice performances I've heard in any game I've played. I feel like it could've left more of a mark on me, but it's also not as if it left [i] no [/i] mark, so... yeah. Thumbs up.

131692303.review:
Psychonauts is one of my favorite games, ever. I grew up playing this on the OG Xbox and I have delved hours into it learning all of its secrets. It's one of Tim's greatest creations and a darn good example of the kind of gold that comes from the team at Double Fine. I cannot recommend this game enough, in fact, you should buy this game for your friends.
There is way too much here to like and pack into one review.
In order to emphasize this, I have to tell you a story.

My first memory is of my dog, Lady. Lady and I used to go for long walks. They would go on and on and on. This one time we went on a walk we called "The Longest Walk of All Time." First, we went to the end of our street. And then we walked three miles. And then we had a snack. And then Lady had to go to the bathroom. And then I bent down to tie my shoe. And then Lady saw a gopher. And then we walked three miles. And then we stopped and asked for directions. And then we got attacked by bees. And then you bought this game.

130794531.review:
Oh man, I feel like I got tricked into playing this game. So many people recommended it online & rated it pretty highly. But this is a 5/10 game imo.

The gameplay, especially the platforming, is janky, frustrating, boring, and not fine-tuned. It makes me appreciate so many other platformers that have tight controls & camera control and have strict rules that make you know you can make a jump on a surface and slide/fall off like I did so many times in this fucking game. The combat mechanics are pretty shallow and boss fights usually come down to figuring out which power the game wants you to use, without much prompting which power that is. They could have used color codes or recurring signs/attacks to telegraph what powers to use, if they wanted to restrict which ones you do use in boss fights. Why all bosses can't be, say, set on fire or picked up with telekinesis? Because the designers had a specific idea in mind and that restricts fun & creativity with such interesting powers.

The second worst part of the game was that it was trying to be a platformer while also trying to be a "collectathon" game. Except the things you are collecting don't make almost any difference in the gameplay & difficulty of the game. I barely felt stronger for collecting so many damn figments and the useless emotional baggage (with a ~7 second cutscene every time that you can't skip). In my opinion, they should have focused on collecting things or on platforming, or if they did both make collecting things have much more impact. And more RPG elements of spending your levels on upgrading specific powers would have made collecting more fun & engaging. As it is, you collect a bunch of stuff to be told a few levels before "Hey! You'll upgrade invisibility! And then never need to use it!" Great.......

The story is on paper somewhat interesting, with psychic secret agents who save the world. But what does the main character do in the game? Go into his friends, teachers, random mental asylum inmates, and villains' minds to solve his problems. He does save the world in the process, but you never feel like the world is in danger, as the entire game takes place in a summer camp & nearby asylum. I didn't care about my actions because I didn't care about the characters. The writing & introduction of each character despite Razputin (the main character) are so weak and random. And there are faaaaaar too many characters for me to care about all of them, which waters down how much I care about each of them in return.

The music wasn't amazing, and there sometimes was no music during parts of levels. The artwork is interesting, but with the jagged edges and repetitious textures during each level.

I'd say the best part of the game was the humor and some jokes were pretty funny :) Those made me smile.....but there were a lot of jokes that tried to hit that just fell flat and were way too random to be funny.

Overall, I do *not* recommend playing this game. Play a better platformer like Super Mario 64 or a better collectathon game like Donkey Kong 64. Ignore what people say, this is a game better left to the past.

130696826.review:
Psychonauts es un juego extraño, me llevó varias horas entender qué estaba pasando y, al ser un juego de 2005, los controles dejan mucho que desear. Sin embargo, una vez que le pillé el tranquillo, me encontré ante un buen juego. La historia tiene lugar en un campamento en el que entrenan a unos niños para convertirlos en guerreros que defiendan el pensamiento libre, pero estos guerreros no usan la fuerza bruta como arma, sino la mente, son conocidos como los psychonauts. Como te podrás imaginar, los diferentes niveles y plataformeo que tiene el juego se desarrollan introduciéndote dentro de la mente de los personajes, de forma que podemos ver su vida pasada, sus miedos, sus aspiraciones y sus traumas. Y en este aspecto es donde brilla Psychonauts: nos presenta la mente y la salud mental de una forma bastante interesante (a partir de aquí hay spoilers). Por ejemplo, hay una mujer llamada Milla que es muy cañera, si nos metemos en su mente, pensaremos que a ella lo único que le gusta es la fiesta y el baile, sin embargo, esto solo es una fachada para ocultar sus traumas debido a que no pudo hacer nada para evitar la muerte de unos niños en un orfanato. También está Edgar, que padece un trastorno obsesivo-compulsivo por circunstancias de su vida, y dicho trastorno se simboliza mediante un toro llamado El Odio, que corre en un bucle infinito entre los recuerdos del pasado de los que se arrepiente y, para salir de ese bucle, debemos ayudar a Edgar a afrontar directamente la causa de su arrepentimiento y dejar el pasado atrás.

El videojuego presenta diversos enemigos según la mente en la que nos hayamos metido, sin embargo, todas las mentes tienen un enemigo en común: los censores. Estos enemigos son unos hombres trajeados que llevan un sello negativo, y atacarán al jugador nada más verlo. Los censores representan una especie de sistema inmune del cerebro, se encargan de eliminar los pensamientos intrusivos y de crear fachadas en el pensamiento con el objetivo de proteger al cerebro, como le ocurre a Milla. La falta de censores en una mente es un indicativo de que esa persona tiene problemas mentales, y un ejemplo de ello es Boyd Cooper, la única persona de todo el juego en la que no encontramos censores al penetrar en su mente. Boyd padece esquizofrenia paranoide, cree en las teorías de la conspiración y siente que está siendo perseguido. Cuando nos introducimos en su mente, vamos a parar a un pueblo que, a priori, parece normal y corriente. Sin embargo, no tardamos en descubrir que la versión distorsionada de la realidad que tiene Boyd se ve reflejada a través de un pueblo deformado que no sigue las leyes de la física ni de la lógica. También vemos su paranoia a través de cámaras y espías por todos lados, así como agentes del Gobierno que buscan a un tal «lechero». Estos agentes eran producto de la imaginación de Boyd y, de forma irónica, su verdadera función consistía en proteger a Boyd de sí mismo, querían encontrar al lechero, que era el alter ego de Boyd, su lado mentalmente estable. Durante todo el nivel, no nos topamos con ningún censor, lo que simboliza que Boyd está totalmente desconectado de la realidad y en su mente hay pensamientos que no deberían estar (ya que no hay censores para eliminarlos). Sin embargo, en cuanto encontramos al lechero, el lado mentalmente estable de Boyd, empiezan a aparecer censores a montones.

Simbolismos como este me han gustado mucho y llevan a recomendar Psychonauts. No es un juego perfecto, obviamente, tiene algunos defectos como los que ya comenté brevemente al inicio, o también el hecho de que no está traducido al español, pero desde luego no es un mal juego.

If you're a fan of adventure games or just enjoy a good laugh, Psychonauts is a must-have. Trust me, you won't be disappointed.

130145587.review: Psychonauts is an absolutely incredible experience. From top to bottom this game is full of personality and unique ideas i've never seen in any other game. The 3D Platforming is superb and strikes a great balance between an action game and a collectathon. 130062559.review:
For a 2005 game it's probably good, but in 2022 it feels lacking, to say the least. Collecting stuff is frustrating, sound design is non-existent at times, a few segments are the game are incredibly frustrating, and across the board the boss battles are pretty unsatisfying (the Milkman's boss is probably the best). Maybe most importantly, for a game that is supposed to be a platformer, any sections where platforming is the focus and missing the platform makes you fall to your death, are absolutely horrendous. You can spend 10 minutes climbing up, get hit by something or miss a jump, and fall down halfway again, and have that be repeated until you beat it. I was tempted to quit the game a few times and just look up a Let's Play of someone clearing the game.

That said, the visuals and the different minds you venture into are amazing and really makes this game unique. A masterpiece in 2005 that has aged very roughly. 

The story is... interesting? If you write out the story it's incredibly short, lengthened by the different individual minds you venture into, however these individuals do not bring the story forward. I'd estimate 75% of the game is helping random, *very interesting* characters that you'll then never interact with again. Perhaps in a sequel, they'll return and bring something interesting to the table, but in this game they could've all been interchanged for any other interesting characters as they don't interact with the plot. It feels like they had a great pitch, only that they weren't sure how to put it all into a coherent story or use all of the fun powers at your disposal.

The "feel" of the game has aged kind of well but is still a bit rough, switching between windows takes a few seconds on Windows 10 for example, and certain controls are unintuitive. I took a pause in playing and didn't know the X button did stuff when I returned because there were no prompts for it (puts away items, cancels menus etc). 

Considering the unique gameplay and visuals, I would recommend it for a one-time playthrough, just keep an eye on your own sanity and *don't* collect everything.

129955331.review:
Getting 100% was another standard collect-a-thon with nice story elements that ended in the most frustrating controller-through the window levels... it's clear quality controll gave up by that point.

approximate amount of time to 100%: 20-30
Estimated achievement difficulty: 5/10 (controls and camera mostly)
Minimum number of playthroughs needed: 1
Multiplayer achievements: No Mutiplayer.
Missable achievements: Yes about 4-5 - Check a guide and save at the right times, Recommend the ones on steam, they are good.
Grinding Achievements: Yes, you have to collect EVERYTHING and then some (not to mention the damned figments.. hundreds of quasi-invisible bits of crap that sometimes hide).
DLC-Only achievements: No.
Time-gated achievements: No.
Speed-run achievements: No. 
RNG-achievements: No.
Does difficulty affect achievements: No difficulty choice.
Unobtainable/glitched achievements: No.

So, as mentioned a lot of this game's problems come with the controlls/camera and it really shows it's age.
The speedruns of this game clocks in at 30 minutes... the rest to 30~ hours is collecting the damned figments. you've been warned.
As for the story... I'm glad you liked it... but if that's the reason you are playing this... Might i recommend you watch a let's play of it... there's many out there.
Same goes for what others love to praise this game for, it's humor and it's unconventional situations... again... check youtube, don't subject yourself to the achievements.

But if you do insist... here's something that will be super usefull.. trust me :
https://gamefaqs.gamespot.com/pc/922157-psychonauts/faqs/48748

oooh and one achievement is literally "show this item to every NPC in the game for no reason than an achievement"... 

So yeah.. steam doesn't allow me to "meh" so I will chose to NOT recommend it... to fix a bit to the lie that is "overwhelmingly positive"

129501584.review: Absolutely insane game. I'm a big fan of mid-oughts and late 90's edge, so I figured this would be extremely 'my thing' but it went above and beyond any kind of expectation I had. The characters are memorable, with genuinely meaningful yet simultaneously comical themes embedded in to give sharp emotional parallels at the drop of a hat yet without too drastic or unfathomable of a shift in tone, and very solid gameplay across the board. Didn't have any issues with this port, it looks great and the experience holds up as, genuinely one of the all-time best platformers if you're looking for just a good fun romp through a ton of twisted yet creative landscapes. Like I said, the gameplay does its job, though the mechanics themselves are nothing really groundbreaking, in a sense they're just 'there' but that's not the point of this title. Really the point here is to experience it from a standpoint of an open mind while exploring other people's minds. I struggle to find flaws really, although I think there's some concepts they could expand upon. 9.75/10

129317180.review:
Psychonauts really shines in its story; I've learned that when point 'n' click writers apply themselves to 3D platformers the characterisation and narrative development will be fantastic. The humour is wonderful and very reminiscent of LucasArts classics. But the boss fights (looking at you, lungfish) are so unintuitive, unwieldy and utterly bugged that I cannot in good faith recommend this game. In other words, poor mechanics let this game down massively. Huge shame. I will update this review with more analysis upon completion, and I am unsure of whether I will change the rating--but right now I am absolutely dreading future boss fights. 

Original updates: 

(1) This is otherwise a 10/10 game. The creativity is insane. The characters are fascinating. If it was possible, I would love to go on a tour inside Tim Schafer's brain, because I'm fairly certain it would look something like the Milkman Conspiracy. However, mediocre boss fights and terribly vague gameplay (clearly an adventure game carry-over) persist. 3D platformers don't have to be linear, but: (a) if baddies are present, combat must be fun and well designed and (b) objectives should be easier to decipher than typical puzzle games because the focus is ultimately on platforming.

(2) Boss fights continue to suffer from vague, unenjoyable design.

(3) I am going to complete this game, but the more I play, the less I enjoy it because of how convoluted it is. Started off so well and took a sharp right turn into awful.

Specific issues:

-Black Velvetopia is a migraine inducing nightmare. These days it would 100% come with an epilepsy warning. Whoever had the idea of implementing fluorescent colours against a black background (when the figment collectibles are also fluorescent and therefore difficult to distinguish?) should have seriously evaluated that decision. Simply horrendous.

-Waterloo World's logic: there is none. Cool idea to reimagine a historical battle, and great VA as always, but shaming the player for not being able to figure out nonsense is unacceptable.

125609450.review:
When I first traversed the unraveling minds of the poor tormented souls in this game I couldn't understand why  I loved it so much.

Was it because it was funny?
Because it was strange?
Perhaps it was that unsettling feeling it gave me deep in my guts.
Well, It was all of those things and so so so so so much more.

Psychonauts is one of the strangest most wonderful pieces of art that exists in this world. 
There are a lot of games out there worth your time but NOTHING is like Psychonauts!
Well, except I guess Psychonauts 2, which is also pretty great. 

If for some reason you have yet to experience Psychonauts, please give it a try.
This is more than just a PS2 era 3D platformer with a unique art style and silly dialogue.
This game deals with some deep issues, not everything is spelled out for you and you will discover new things by revisiting minds, and when you will undoubtedly replay this game a second time.

I don't just recommend this game, I am actively begging you to play it.

125410852.review:
[h1]Short review : [/h1]
Psychonauts is a 2005 collect-a-thon game that gives you the opportunity to play as a psychic going from minds to minds to uncover a mystery. The particularity is that every level is an original representation of someone’s mind, and it’s presented in a very creative and colourful way. If the game is very interesting for its aesthetics and its ideas, the gameplay is not always enjoyable as the controls can feel a bit clunky and some of the collectibles are infuriating to collect. 
Despite all this, one should at least try psychonauts to taste the originality and uniqueness of the title but shouldn’t be bothered to complete it as it can quickly become frustrating. 

[h1]I.Form[/h1]
[b]a.Graphics[/b]
Psychonauts is far from being the best-looking game from 2005. That doesn’t mean that it looks bad. One of the strong elements of the game is its aesthetic. Think of classic 3D platformers such as Banjo&Kazooie meets comic books and Tim Burton. Psychonauts knows its aesthetic and actually offers something well put together, no matter the limitation of the time. 

[b]b.Music and Voice Acting[/b]
Music is not that special, most of the time you won’t pay attention to it. Nothing is groundbreaking and most of the time the OST doesn’t know what vibe it wants to give to the game. Sometimes typical spy-movie tunes, sometimes western, sometimes melodious. It’s very hard to know. 
The voice acting is okay, good even but sadly the repetitions of the same sentences over and over again combined with some atrocious voice choices (sheegor for example) makes it sometimes hard to enjoy.

[h1]II.Content[/h1]
[b]a.Gameplay[/b]
The game is a classic collect-a-thon platformer. You go from “world” to “world” and collect things withing those levels. The twist that psychonauts wants to offer is that you are a young psychic and you go inside the mind of people to get more powerful. You also get psychic powers along the way and each of those powers allows you to collect new things. 
The main collectibles are figments (sorts of jpg pictures hanging in multiple places in the level, usually more than 100 are placed in each levels), emotional baggage and vaults. Figments are the reason I never bothered finishing the game in the past, they are very hard to see on screen sometimes and they are just annoying to collect altogether. In some level its just pure torture to look for them. You don’t have to do it but it’s necessary for levelling up your character and of course do the 101% run. 
Also, I know the game is more than 15 years old now but the controls are sometimes infuriating. I felt the need to stop playing the game at multiple points as they would introduce some weird mechanics or ask to do some kind of infuriating parkour. The jump is neither precise, nor fluid, it’s just stiff. You need to get use to it and when I say need, it’s that it’s mandatory as one of the final level of the game is a super long and very difficult parkour where you can’t stop or make the smallest mistake. 
Altogether the game can be very fun to explore but also incredibly frustrating to navigate and 100%

[b]b.Story[/b]
Psychonauts tells the story of a summer camp for psychic children. There they are supposed to develop their skills and become psychic soldiers. You play as Raz one of those children and quickly you’ll notice that something darker happens at the camp as you navigate inside people’s mind to get stronger.
That’s the strongest aspect of the game; That idea of exploring the mind of people and that it looks like a completely different thing depending on the person personality. You can have a war-zone or a board game or even a whole city. That’s absolutely captivating and motivation enough to put your frustrations aside and keep playing the game to see what’s next. 
The fact that it’s a camp setting is also super nice because outside of those levels you can do what children in camp do and explore the surroundings, it feels very organic, very believable. It’s definitely something that added to the game for me. I’m curious if the sequel will go back to it and if not what they will offer instead. 

[h1]III.Others[/h1]
[b]a.Replay Value[/b]
You’ll need to play a bit more after finishing the game if you want to complete it but after that I don’t see many reasons to inflict that upon yourself again. You’ll probably return to re-experience the story and atmosphere but that’s it.

[b]b.Achievements[/b] 
The game has 37 achievements and a few are actually missable and unless you know about them it’s very easy to miss them as the game never signal a special event taking place. Also the completion of the game is super infuriating. Finding all the figments is a chore and when a level has more than 200 of those electric-colour things in front of an electric-colored background it’s just insane. 

[b]c.Price[/b] 
The game is 9.99 but goes on sale quite often. I would rather wait for a sale as the game is very not that big nor long. 

[h1]IV.Pros and Cons[/h1]
[Table]
[tr][th]Pros[/th][th]Cons[/th][/tr]
[tr][td][list]
    [*] A cool and unique universe and atmosphere
    [*] Cool characters and worlds
 [/list][/td]
[td][list]
    [*] Annoying / Frustrating controls 
    [*] Collecting is draining and tedious 
[/list][/td][/tr]
[tr][th]Conclusion[/th][td]★★★☆☆ [/td][/tr]
[/table]

124008530.review:
Not to sound like the Youtuber Penguinz as a teenager, but Psychonauts is my favorite video game of all time. This game shaped my life as dorky as that sounds, and throughout my life I've all but wanted to tie every friend and family member I have to a chair and make them play this game. I legitimately play other platformers and get a feeling in my gut that I'd rather be playing this, and I say that with platformers being my favorite genre.

To me the best type of game is a 3D platformer collectathon with secrets around every nook and cranny, a game you can fully lose yourself in the world and plot of while also playing for fun or obsessively seeking out every single collectible. This game perfects that description. I always fall into the second category and I like to 100% this game for fun or whenever I'm feeling down. It's important with a collectathon that you never tire of the characters, art, or music, because you're going to be seeing A LOT of them. I first played this game as a child and the world it presents has never grown stale.
It's one of those games where you can feel the creators passion for it in every detail.

As far as story it isn't anything insane or that'll make you cry, but it's a fun set piece for the game to rest on and it has enough to it that you won't be comparing it to overly simple platformer stories like Mario and A Hat In Time.
The game's sense of humor is amazing and still makes me laugh to this day, even the way the lines are delivered is perfection. As a teenager during one of my escapades of forcing my friends to play this game, shortly into it my friend asked me if I had been playing this since I was really little, I told them I had, and they replied that it made perfect sense where I got my sense of humor from, which shows the way the writing and delivery shaped me.
The game even delves into dark humor at times which I adore, without overly relying on it like a Danganronpa game might.
Even if you don't 100% the game try to get all of the memory vaults! It's well worth your time for the extra art, addition to the story, and several touching moments in the wordless storytelling that always gets me tearing up.

The art direction in this game is brilliant, Scott Campbell's work is unique and pulls you in, but I've found that it's not for everyone since some people I show this game to will remark that the art leans more "weird" than pretty to them, which might tip some people off. (Not me!) The art still influences me in what I draw to this day, and I always keep art from this game up on my wall to inspire me.

One flaw the art has in this game lies mainly in its 100% completion requirements. No spoilers but there is a race segment of the game. The walls are very groovy and colorful with fun patterns on everything and it looks pretty as you whiz by it all. The race only takes a minute or two to complete, so you won't be there long, however if you are 100% completing the game you'll find yourself coming back to this race, albeit this time a bit more slowly. Pacing over every inch of the racing track looking for figment collectibles that often blend in to the colorful designs is a NIGHTMARE. You'll find yourself missing plenty and if you want to walk backwards it'll be a pain in the ass since the track is sloped for forward movement only. Whenever I look for figments in the game I save this for last as I detest it, and I quickly get motion sick 10-20 min into exploring the race track. On that note there are a few figments that are overly difficult to find. One of which feels like it's in the middle of nowhere and I've heard many miss that one. I had to look up where figments are placed (Luckily with the game giving you a book of your collected ones it's VERY simple to follow guides for these) and I HATE looking up collectible placement. One I missed was green, see through, and looked like a tree. It was in a backyard area that was hard to center the camera on and in GREEN grass. I was pissed when I finally found it. The game does what I think all collectible games should do and lists how many of each item you're missing in each sub area AND level, but don't feel guilty if you have to look one up!

The gameplay hasn't changed much since its Xbox/PS2 days, but I love the way Raz feels and controls, the platforming is so much fun to learn and perfect over time, but the game never gets overly difficult, just enough to make you feel proud of yourself for getting through parts without making you angry. I've heard some people say Raz controls "janky" and doesn't respond how they want or expect him to, and while I don't notice this it is something that I could have grown blind to over years of playing, though I remember it feeling amazing even as a child.

The music is charming and expressive though not very emotional. The game wants you to have fun more than cry your eyes out. It's very recognizable as I played through Costume Quest and found a camping store in it that played Psychonauts music, I realized what it was right away and was thrilled. It's not even the only Psychonauts Easter egg in the game, or in games in general, which shows the cult following it has amassed. From Brutal Legend to Alice Madness Returns many games have taken to referencing it.

All together if you like 3D platformers or even if you just like the art and humor, go check this game out, as I'm sure it'll continue to inspire people for years to come.

I am the milk man. My milk is delicious… I tell my wife’s boyfriend every night.

I do not like 3d platformers. Mario 64? Don't like it. Banjo Kazooie? Don't like it.

Psychonauts? F***king love it. This game transcends the genre. The visuals, humor, gameplay...all of it. F***king flawless.

Psychonauts is an adventure game with the skin of a platformer. If you go in thinking it will be a platformer none of the challenges will make sense. If you go in knowing it is an adventure game you will be right at home.

I remember a men’s magazine from like 2005 recommending this game as brilliant and a must play. I still have that magazine, although the pages are a bit sticky now.  I never played the game though and I missed out by wasting my time with dozens of AAA games instead.

It’s one my favorite games now though, and I’m not even blinded by nostalgia or anything. My wife’s boyfriend just decided to gift it to me during a sale for like 1 dollar a few years back and I’ve loved it ever since. 

I love the style, the charm, fun, inventiveness....start to (nearly finish) its magnificent. The way that each level captures the mental affliction and persona of the protagonist is nothing short of sublime.

In many a drunken debate I've claimed that I think it's a perfect "yes answer" for "are games art?". I always use the bull run level as proof.

If you havent played this marvellous game, play it; after all - who doesn't love bacon?

10/10

123712861.review:
I received this game as a Christmas gift from a close friend of mine last year.
Psychonauts is a fun platformer from that released during the 6th generation of game consoles. For being an Xbox/PS2 title, this game looks extremely good. The graphics have aged well due to how stylized they are.
The main campaign will probably average around a good 12-15 hours depending on the person. If you go for 100% you're probably looking at around 24 hours.
I honestly wouldn't recommend going for 100% unless this game becomes your favorite, there's a lot that goes into it. You'll probably have to do a lot of googling to figure out exactly what you need to do to grab the 3 figments you missed. Figments are scattered through each main level, and count towards 100%. Once you get farther into the game, you can be finding 100s of them in a single level, some extremely difficult and taking precision to grab.
I personally had wanted to play this game for years before going for a Steam copy, I hunted for the PS2 version through some of my teenage years, but never managed to find one. So my expectations for this game were fairly high.
This game floods personality and charm, and honestly that right there was enough to give this game an easy recommendation. Most of the platforming is fun, and the puzzles range from very simple to, "I would have never figured that out on my own." Using your psychic powers to solve puzzles is one of the many things that made this a fun experience. The story, while by today's standards has a few slightly predictable elements is cute. Even with the predictability it still had a ton of unique elements that I adored.
I think the only main con with this game is how it runs, it's from 2005. I ran into some glitches and bugs that could only be fixed with a reinstall. I had a small amount of crashes, but nothing in the vain of playing Fallout New Vegas. It runs decently on Windows 10, but not perfectly. Luckily there's a FAQ pinned to the official forums, that the creator of the game posted. Most of the time, that will give you exactly what you need to know. 
For $10, this game is definitely worth your time. It's become a bit of a cult classic, especially when considering the Xbox's game library. Plus, last year we got a sequel so there's no better time to pick this one up. I consider this one to be worth the years of waiting I did to see it, and what it has to offer. This is a good one, a creatively good one.

123091742.review:
Psychonauts is a classic from the tail end of the 3D platformer boom from the mid-90s to mid-2000s. It mixes 3D platforming with elements of exploration and inventory puzzles from the adventure game genre. This is from Double Fine's staff at the time of development mostly working on Adventure games in the 90s.

The result is there's a lot of unique dialogue for showing your inventory items to every character possible. The dialogue and writing are stellar and the true selling point of this game. There's a unique premise that psychics exist, they have a pan-national spy agency, and your player character breaks into that organization's summer camp for psychically gifted children. You have a cast of campers and councilors who are distinctly written and well voice-acted. The hub world is the camp itself and manages to feel big and full of secrets without actually being that big. The individual levels are the minds of different people around the camp. Going into the brain of a person allows for stylization of aesthetics and a focus on how that person perceives the world.

On a technical level the platforming can be a bit on the easy side. Once unlocking the ability to levitate, many of the levels and sections of the overworld open up and make collecting hard-to-reach objects much easier. Some in-level collectibles have a color palette similar to their backgrounds that can make seeing them difficult. These collectibles also float along a track which can means spending extra time per collectible. These are minor nitpicks and only an issue if you try to go for 100% completion.

122650148.review:
I'm probably going to be killed for saying this but I don't think Psychonauts is very good.
Don't get me wrong its very unique and interesting. But that doesn't make it fun to play.


I don't think its too controversial to say the game's level design is awful.
Every single mindscape is full of back tracking and wonky platforming, Raz just doesn't control well. His jump feels stiff, he's very slow and don't even try to attack enemies it just feels like crap. Even with a controller.
Navigation is a pain. Despite being psychic Raz has no compass or map so figuring out each objective is something of a journey in discovery. Which sounds good in theory but again, its slow and awkward and just not fun.
Platforming is awful, physics based sections like the trapeze feel VERY stiff. There's no flow for momentum at all. Raz's double jump is just useless. You can't really change your direction or alter your jump length. There's no reason not to just mash out a double jump every time because you never need a single jump. It makes platforming feel less a challenge of judgement and reflex, more like you're just walking down a funny shaped hallway. 

By my count the best part of the game is also the worst. The first three hours are one giant over long very hand-holdy tutorial but also the minds you explore during this time are not only richly detailed and oozing with good foreshadowing and subtle world building. They are also the easiest and most navigable. Even if the course of action devolves into a "Get item C from mind B so you can get item D for mind A" kind of Spongebobbing fetch quest stuff. 
Boss fights are a pain, its the standard kid friendly wait five minutes for them to expose a glowing weak spot then hit it once and repeat about 3-4 times. 

As for the writing well, Psychonauts is at its best when its trying to be serious. 
There is some great foreshadowing, even many throw away lines contain a hint about whats to come next or about a character's inner struggles. Every single mind you enter is full of detail and metaphor, which makes for interesting speculation in a very thought provoking story.

However humour is a difficult thing to get right and Psychonauts fails hard. 
Its a good dozen steps above video game humour There's no "Gamers don't die they just respawn" type jokes, but Psychonauts forgets the two most basic rules of comedy. Timing and shock. Many of the jokes drag on just a little too far or simply aren't shocking enough to get your attention. 
Despite having a fantastically written cast there's precious few character jokes, most of the humour boils down to "Wouldn't it be funny if the main villain's astral form was a Ultraman reference?" a joke that was probably lost on all the players back in 2005.

I am willing to admit it might just be an issue of taste where the humour is found and not really something quantifiable. 

Graphics might be a point of contention for some but not me. Sure the game looks ugly but I've seen far worse. Psychonauts is definitely a triumph of art direction over pure graphical power. Its far more interesting to look at a character like Sasha Nein or Coach Oliander and see the unique personality in their designs or in their mindscapes than anything game like Control that just showers you in fancy high end particle effects could ever offer.

Sound on the other hand...
I'm not sure why everything is so compressed but its kind of funny to imagine the whole game's story being told through a 2008 Xbox 360 party chat. 
Jokes aside all the sound is very compressed and it is genuinely awful. 

Overall Psychonauts as a story or setting is interesting. The way it portrays mental illness is something I wish more games would do. The mindscapes are all beautiful and fascinating absolutely rich with symbolism and detail. But its just not fun to play. It would be better suited ironically enough as something more like Rhombus of Ruin, a linear point n click style experience. The platforming doesn't add anything it just makes me want to play the game less. 

While I didn't personally enjoy it perhaps someone who doesn't already know the story of the game might.

120470447.review: I CAN NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME ENOUGH! Very fun platforming! VERY fun and charming story and characters. The art style is magic to look at and wonderful compliments the tone of the game. The concept of looking into people's minds is explored to it's FULL extent and leaves you always gains new incites into certain characters by simply exploring their level. It's not a flawless game however, no matter how much I love it. It's exploration of different mentalities and mental illnesses are researched to varying degrees of success. There's also a case of the protagonist using a Romani slur when referring to his family. Still, I believe the base messages within the game about empathy and sympathy for those going through different internal battles then ourselves stands true and elevates the whole experience. I will not hesitate to say that if I had gotten my hands on this game at a much younger age it would have helped me to understand some parts of myself that left me confused. I also feel it's wrong on me to harp too much on the developers of this game when they did so much to fix these issues I have and more in the sequel. Anyhow, this game feels like an essential part of any avid platformer fan's collection and I sincerely hope you're able to enjoy this game as much as I did.

120241660.review:
[h1][b][i]I played both 1, Rhombus of Ruin, and 2 back to back, and excluding RoR, the two games are *very* similar and act as an extension of one another. This is why this review will include my general opinions about both 1 *and* 2, while pointing out some differences between them. Generally though, if I didn't mention which entry I'm talking about, then I'm talking about both.[/i][/b][/h1]

[h1]Story & Writing:[/h1]

[b]This is the series strong-point by far. Every aspect of the game feeds into the story, including: level-design, combat, abilities, etc.[/b]

The story itself in it's base form isn't something we've never seen before: superpowers, gadgets, spies, etc. [u]It's the way the story bleeds into every nook and cranny of this game[/u], the way the writing can pull off seem-less transitions between childish humour, adult drama, or sometimes in between with adult comedy.

All the characters are well written, and are some of the most memorable I've seen in any movie, show, or game.

After playing this series, All other similar games' stories (Jack and Daxter, Ratchet and clank, Sly Cooper) feel one-dimensional and basic. Especially after playing Ratchet and Clack: Rift Apart, which felt very child focused and not very enjoyable or engaging for anyone above the age of 10.

[i]Between the first game and the second , I feel both are as strong as one another writing wise, and although the first one has a very good story, the sequel ups it by just a bit.[/i]

[h1]Level-Design:[/h1]

Since most of the game takes place in different people's minds, [b]the level design feels like a continuation of the story[/b], but without the writing. You can see the world through the person's POV and delve into his psyche to figure out what are his internal problems, motivations, etc. [u]Everything in the level is a hint into the subconscious[/u]: the characters, the walls, the gimmick....

[b]every level has it's own unique gimmick which can be minor or major.[/b] It can range from for example: 1-the floor is lava, 2- giving you a new ability and the whole level is built around this ability (which you can now use in other levels of course), or 3- completely changing the way you play the game.

[i]In this aspect, I think both 1 and 2 are equal, though 2 is bigger and offers more.[/i]

[h1]Combat & Powers:[/h1]

[b]Combat is serviceable[/b], [i]although there is a definite improvement with the second game[/i] with more enemy variety, while the first game only had censors of the small, medium,  large and range variety, three of them basically occupying the same role.

Although, with the introduction of more enemies in the second game, some of them have a specific way to fight them and although I didn't mind most of them, some take almost no damage expect with pyrokinesis which is very slow and tedious.

[b]Lock-on was extremely well-done in the first game, and it's absolutely horrendous in the second one, you might as well not use it in 2.[/b]

as for powers, both games have the same core abilities with a few specific powers for each game. The main point I would like to talk about is the differences in 3 of the main abilities between the first and second game.

Psi-blast: Is a basic shoot ability in both games with a charge mechanic, in the first game it's ammo based, while in the second game it's 3 shots (you can also upgrade to 4, feels pretty much the same) and then a cooldown. Both have their negatives, in the first one when you have a lot of ammo you basically dont need any other power, but when you're out you have collect drops one by one which is tedious and breaks flow. In the second game, it's rechargeable so it can be used in the platforming like the other abilities, but it has more down-time than shooting. I feel there is a middle ground here.

Pyrokinesis: in the first game it was lock on based, which makes it free-range, as long as you can lock on you can use it, but it was also mostly a single target attack, in the second game it's an AOE with well defined parameters but only a fixed range. Also both require a wind-up. I feel also, there is a middle ground here and you can also remove the wind-up but give it a slight recharge time.

Levitation: It was by far, way more fun to use in the first game than in the second game. It had higher jumps, more control and just better movements in the first game. While I understand why they nerfed it, since you can break the game with it and they had to be very intricate in their design with the first game to make sure this doesn't happen for the most part (it still did), but in the end, it is less fun to use in the second game.

[h1][b][i][u]TL;DR: Fantastic action-platformer with genre defining story, writing and characters.[/u][/i][/b][/h1]

אֱלֹהִים֮ אֶת־הָרָקִיעַ֒ וַיַּבְדֵּ֗ל בֵּ֤ין הַמַּ֙יִם֙ אֲשֶׁר֙ מִתַּ֣חַת לָרָקִ֔יעַ וּבֵ֣ין הַמַּ֔יִם אֲשֶׁ֖ר מֵעַ֣ל לָרָקִ֑יעַ וַֽיְהִי־כֵֽן׃ (ח) וַיִּקְרָ֧א אֱלֹהִ֛ים לָֽרָקִ֖יעַ שָׁמָ֑יִם וַֽיְהִי־עֶ֥רֶב וַֽיְהִי־בֹ֖קֶר י֥וֹם שֵׁנִֽי׃ (פ) (ט) וַיֹּ֣אמֶר אֱלֹהִ֗ים יִקָּו֨וּ הַמַּ֜יִם מִתַּ֤חַת הַשָּׁמַ֙יִם֙ אֶל־מָק֣וֹם אֶחָ֔ד וְתֵרָאֶ֖ה הַיַּבָּשָׁ֑ה וַֽיְהִי־כֵֽן׃ (י) וַיִּקְרָ֨א אֱלֹהִ֤ים ׀ לַיַּבָּשָׁה֙ אֶ֔רֶץ וּלְמִקְוֵ֥ה הַמַּ֖יִם קָרָ֣א יַמִּ֑ים וַיַּ֥רְא אֱלֹהִ֖ים כִּי־טֽוֹב׃ (יא) וַיֹּ֣אמֶר אֱלֹהִ֗ים תַּֽדְשֵׁ֤א הָאָ֙רֶץ֙ דֶּ֔שֶׁא עֵ֚שֶׂב מַזְרִ֣יעַ זֶ֔רַע עֵ֣ץ פְּרִ֞י עֹ֤שֶׂה פְּרִי֙ לְמִינ֔וֹ אֲשֶׁ֥ר זַרְעוֹ־ב֖וֹ עַל־הָאָ֑רֶץ וַֽיְהִי־כֵֽן׃ (יב) וַתּוֹצֵ֨א הָאָ֜רֶץ דֶּ֠שֶׁא עֵ֣שֶׂב מַזְרִ֤יעַ זֶ֙רַע֙ לְמִינֵ֔הוּ וְעֵ֧ץ עֹֽשֶׂה־פְּרִ֛י אֲשֶׁ֥ר זַרְעוֹ־ב֖וֹ לְמִינֵ֑הוּ וַיַּ֥רְא אֱלֹהִ֖ים כִּי־טֽוֹב׃ (יג) וַֽיְהִי־עֶ֥רֶב וַֽיְהִי־בֹ֖קֶר י֥וֹם שְׁלִישִֽׁי׃ (פ) (יד) וַיֹּ֣אמֶר אֱלֹהִ֗ים יְהִ֤י מְאֹרֹת֙ בִּרְקִ֣יעַ הַשָּׁמַ֔יִם לְהַבְדִּ֕יל בֵּ֥ין הַיּ֖וֹם וּבֵ֣ין הַלָּ֑יְלָה וְהָי֤וּ לְאֹתֹת֙ וּלְמ֣וֹעֲדִ֔ים וּלְיָמִ֖ים וְשָׁנִֽים׃ (טו) וְהָי֤וּ לִמְאוֹרֹת֙ בִּרְקִ֣יעַ הַשָּׁמַ֔יִם לְהָאִ֖יר עַל־הָאָ֑רֶץ וַֽיְהִי־כֵֽן׃ (טז) וַיַּ֣עַשׂ אֱלֹהִ֔ים אֶת־שְׁנֵ֥י הַמְּאֹרֹ֖ת הַגְּדֹלִ֑ים אֶת־הַמָּא֤וֹר הַגָּדֹל֙ לְמֶמְשֶׁ֣לֶת הַיּ֔וֹם וְאֶת־הַמָּא֤וֹר הַקָּטֹן֙ לְמֶמְשֶׁ֣לֶת הַלַּ֔יְלָה וְאֵ֖ת הַכּוֹכָבִֽים׃ (יז) וַיִּתֵּ֥ן אֹתָ֛ם אֱלֹהִ֖ים בִּרְקִ֣יעַ הַשָּׁמָ֑יִם לְהָאִ֖יר עַל־הָאָֽרֶץ׃ (יח) וְלִמְשֹׁל֙ בַּיּ֣וֹם וּבַלַּ֔יְלָה וּֽלֲהַבְדִּ֔יל בֵּ֥ין הָא֖וֹר וּבֵ֣ין הַחֹ֑שֶׁךְ וַיַּ֥רְא אֱלֹהִ֖ים כִּי־טֽוֹב׃ (יט) וַֽיְהִי־עֶ֥רֶב וַֽיְהִי־בֹ֖קֶר י֥וֹם רְבִיעִֽי׃ (פ) (כ) וַיֹּ֣אמֶר אֱלֹהִ֔ים יִשְׁרְצ֣וּ הַמַּ֔יִם שֶׁ֖רֶץ נֶ֣פֶשׁ חַיָּ֑ה וְעוֹף֙ יְעוֹפֵ֣ף עַל־הָאָ֔רֶץ עַל־פְּנֵ֖י רְקִ֥יעַ הַשָּׁמָֽיִם׃ (כא) וַיִּבְרָ֣א אֱלֹהִ֔ים אֶת־הַתַּנִּינִ֖ם הַגְּדֹלִ֑ים וְאֵ֣ת כָּל־נֶ֣פֶשׁ הַֽחַיָּ֣ה ׀ הָֽרֹמֶ֡שֶׂת אֲשֶׁר֩ שָׁרְצ֨וּ הַמַּ֜יִם לְמִֽינֵהֶ֗ם וְאֵ֨ת כָּל־ע֤וֹף כָּנָף֙ לְמִינֵ֔הוּ וַיַּ֥רְא אֱלֹהִ֖ים כִּי־טֽוֹב׃ (כב) וַיְבָ֧רֶךְ אֹתָ֛ם אֱלֹהִ֖ים לֵאמֹ֑ר פְּר֣וּ וּרְב֗וּ וּמִלְא֤וּ אֶת־הַמַּ֙יִם֙ בַּיַּמִּ֔ים וְהָע֖וֹף יִ֥רֶב בָּאָֽרֶץ׃ (כג) וַֽיְהִי־עֶ֥רֶב וַֽיְהִי־בֹ֖קֶר י֥וֹם חֲמִישִֽׁי׃ (פ) (כד) וַיֹּ֣אמֶר אֱלֹהִ֗ים תּוֹצֵ֨א הָאָ֜רֶץ נֶ֤פֶשׁ חַיָּה֙ לְמִינָ֔הּ בְּהֵמָ֥ה וָרֶ֛מֶשׂ וְחַֽיְתוֹ־אֶ֖רֶץ לְמִינָ֑הּ וַֽיְהִי־כֵֽן׃ (כה) וַיַּ֣עַשׂ אֱלֹהִים֩ אֶת־חַיַּ֨ת הָאָ֜רֶץ לְמִינָ֗הּ וְאֶת־הַבְּהֵמָה֙ לְמִינָ֔הּ וְאֵ֛ת כָּל־רֶ֥מֶשׂ הָֽאֲדָמָ֖ה לְמִינֵ֑הוּ וַיַּ֥רְא אֱלֹהִ֖ים כִּי־טֽוֹב׃ (כו) וַיֹּ֣אמֶר אֱלֹהִ֔ים נַֽעֲשֶׂ֥ה אָדָ֛ם בְּצַלְמֵ֖נוּ כִּדְמוּתֵ֑נוּ וְיִרְדּוּ֩ בִדְגַ֨ת הַיָּ֜ם וּבְע֣וֹף הַשָּׁמַ֗יִם וּבַבְּהֵמָה֙ וּבְכָל־הָאָ֔רֶץ וּבְכָל־הָרֶ֖מֶשׂ הָֽרֹמֵ֥שׂ עַל־הָאָֽרֶץ׃ (כז) וַיִּבְרָ֨א אֱלֹהִ֤ים ׀ אֶת־הָֽאָדָם֙ בְּצַלְמ֔וֹ בְּצֶ֥לֶם אֱלֹהִ֖ים בָּרָ֣א אֹת֑וֹ זָכָ֥ר וּנְקֵבָ֖ה בָּרָ֥א אֹתָֽם׃ (כח) וַיְבָ֣רֶךְ אֹתָם֮ אֱלֹהִים֒ וַיֹּ֨אמֶר לָהֶ֜ם אֱלֹהִ֗ים פְּר֥וּ וּרְב֛וּ וּמִלְא֥וּ אֶת־הָאָ֖רֶץ וְכִבְשֻׁ֑הָ וּרְד֞וּ בִּדְגַ֤ת הַיָּם֙ וּבְע֣וֹף הַשָּׁמַ֔יִם וּבְכָל־חַיָּ֖ה הָֽרֹמֶ֥שֶׂת עַל־הָאָֽרֶץ׃ (כט) וַיֹּ֣אמֶר אֱלֹהִ֗ים הִנֵּה֩ נָתַ֨תִּי לָכֶ֜ם אֶת־כָּל־עֵ֣שֶׂב ׀ זֹרֵ֣עַ זֶ֗רַע אֲשֶׁר֙ עַל־פְּנֵ֣י כָל־הָאָ֔רֶץ וְאֶת־כָּל־הָעֵ֛ץ אֲשֶׁר־בּ֥וֹ פְרִי־עֵ֖ץ זֹרֵ֣עַ זָ֑רַע לָכֶ֥ם יִֽהְיֶ֖ה לְאָכְלָֽה׃ (ל) וּֽלְכָל־חַיַּ֣ת הָ֠אָרֶץ וּלְכָל־ע֨וֹף הַשָּׁמַ֜יִם וּלְכֹ֣ל ׀ רוֹמֵ֣שׂ עַל־הָאָ֗רֶץ אֲשֶׁר־בּוֹ֙ נֶ֣פֶשׁ חַיָּ֔ה אֶת־כָּל־יֶ֥רֶק עֵ֖שֶׂב לְאָכְלָ֑ה וַֽיְהִי־כֵֽן׃ (לא) וַיַּ֤רְא אֱלֹהִים֙ אֶת־כָּל־אֲשֶׁ֣ר עָשָׂ֔ה וְהִנֵּה־ט֖וֹב מְאֹ֑ד וַֽיְהִי־עֶ֥רֶב וַֽיְהִי־בֹ֖קֶר י֥וֹם הַשִּׁשִּֽׁי׃ (פ)
ב
(א) וַיְכֻלּ֛וּ הַשָּׁמַ֥יִם וְהָאָ֖רֶץ וְכָל־צְבָאָֽם׃ (ב) וַיְכַ֤ל אֱלֹהִים֙ בַּיּ֣וֹם הַשְּׁבִיעִ֔י מְלַאכְתּ֖וֹ אֲשֶׁ֣ר עָשָׂ֑ה וַיִּשְׁבֹּת֙ בַּיּ֣וֹם הַשְּׁבִיעִ֔י מִכָּל־מְלַאכְתּ֖וֹ אֲשֶׁ֥ר עָשָֽׂה׃ (ג) וַיְבָ֤רֶךְ אֱלֹהִים֙ אֶת־י֣וֹם הַשְּׁבִיעִ֔י וַיְקַדֵּ֖שׁ אֹת֑וֹ כִּ֣י ב֤וֹ שָׁבַת֙ מִכָּל־מְלַאכְתּ֔וֹ אֲשֶׁר־בָּרָ֥א אֱלֹהִ֖ים לַעֲשֽׂוֹת׃ (פ) (ד) אֵ֣לֶּה תוֹלְד֧וֹת הַשָּׁמַ֛יִם וְהָאָ֖רֶץ בְּהִבָּֽרְאָ֑ם בְּי֗וֹם עֲשׂ֛וֹת יְהוָ֥ה אֱלֹהִ֖ים אֶ֥רֶץ וְשָׁמָֽיִם׃ (ה) וְכֹ֣ל ׀ שִׂ֣יחַ הַשָּׂדֶ֗ה טֶ֚רֶם יִֽהְיֶ֣ה בָאָ֔רֶץ וְכָל־עֵ֥שֶׂב הַשָּׂדֶ֖ה טֶ֣רֶם יִצְמָ֑ח כִּי֩ לֹ֨א הִמְטִ֜יר יְהוָ֤ה אֱלֹהִים֙ עַל־הָאָ֔רֶץ וְאָדָ֣ם אַ֔יִן לַֽעֲבֹ֖ד אֶת־הָֽאֲדָמָֽה׃ (ו) וְאֵ֖ד יַֽעֲלֶ֣ה מִן־הָאָ֑רֶץ וְהִשְׁקָ֖ה אֶֽת־כָּל־פְּנֵֽי־הָֽאֲדָמָֽה׃ (ז) וַיִּיצֶר֩ יְהוָ֨ה אֱלֹהִ֜ים אֶת־הָֽאָדָ֗ם עָפָר֙ מִן־הָ֣אֲדָמָ֔ה וַיִּפַּ֥ח בְּאַפָּ֖יו נִשְׁמַ֣ת חַיִּ֑ים וַֽיְהִ֥י הָֽאָדָ֖ם לְנֶ֥פֶשׁ חַיָּֽה׃ (ח) וַיִּטַּ֞ע יְהוָ֧ה אֱלֹהִ֛ים גַּן־בְעֵ֖דֶן מִקֶּ֑דֶם וַיָּ֣שֶׂם שָׁ֔ם אֶת־הָֽאָדָ֖ם אֲשֶׁ֥ר יָצָֽר׃ (ט) וַיַּצְמַ֞ח יְהוָ֤ה אֱלֹהִים֙ מִן־הָ֣אֲדָמָ֔ה כָּל־עֵ֛ץ נֶחְמָ֥ד לְמַרְאֶ֖ה וְט֣וֹב לְמַאֲכָ֑ל וְעֵ֤ץ הַֽחַיִּים֙ בְּת֣וֹךְ הַגָּ֔ן וְעֵ֕ץ הַדַּ֖עַת ט֥וֹב וָרָֽע׃ (י) וְנָהָרּ֙ יֹצֵ֣א מֵעֵ֔דֶן לְהַשְׁק֖וֹת אֶת־הַגָּ֑ן וּמִשָּׁם֙ יִפָּרֵ֔ד וְהָיָ֖ה לְאַרְבָּעָ֥ה רָאשִֽׁים׃ (יא) שֵׁ֥ם הָֽאֶחָ֖ד פִּישׁ֑וֹן ה֣וּא הַסֹּבֵ֗ב אֵ֚ת כָּל־אֶ֣רֶץ הַֽחֲוִילָ֔ה אֲשֶׁר־שָׁ֖ם הַזָּהָֽב׃ (יב) וּֽזֲהַ֛ב הָאָ֥רֶץ הַהִ֖וא ט֑וֹב שָׁ֥ם הַבְּדֹ֖לַח וְאֶ֥בֶן הַשֹּֽׁהַם׃ (יג) וְשֵֽׁם־הַנָּהָ֥ר הַשֵּׁנִ֖י גִּיח֑וֹן ה֣וּא הַסּוֹבֵ֔ב אֵ֖ת כָּל־אֶ֥רֶץ כּֽוּשׁ׃ (יד) וְשֵׁ֨ם הַנָּהָ֤ר הַשְּׁלִישִׁי֙ חִדֶּ֔קֶל ה֥וּא הַֽהֹלֵ֖ךְ קִדְמַ֣ת אַשּׁ֑וּר וְהַנָּהָ֥ר הָֽרְבִיעִ֖י ה֥וּא פְרָֽת׃ (טו) וַיִּקַּ֛ח יְהוָ֥ה אֱלֹהִ֖ים אֶת־הָֽאָדָ֑ם וַיַּנִּחֵ֣הוּ בְגַן־עֵ֔דֶן לְעָבְדָ֖הּ וּלְשָׁמְרָֽהּ׃ (טז) וַיְצַו֙ יְהוָ֣ה אֱלֹהִ֔ים עַל־הָֽאָדָ֖ם לֵאמֹ֑ר מִכֹּ֥ל עֵֽץ־הַגָּ֖ן אָכֹ֥ל תֹּאכֵֽל׃ (יז) וּמֵעֵ֗ץ הַדַּ֙עַת֙ ט֣וֹב וָרָ֔ע לֹ֥א תֹאכַ֖ל מִמֶּ֑נּוּ כִּ֗י בְּי֛וֹם אֲכָלְךָ֥ מִמֶּ֖נּוּ מ֥וֹת תָּמֽוּת׃ (יח) וַיֹּ֙אמֶר֙ יְהוָ֣ה אֱלֹהִ֔ים לֹא־ט֛וֹב הֱי֥וֹת הָֽאָדָ֖ם לְבַדּ֑וֹ אֶֽעֱשֶׂהּ־לּ֥וֹ עֵ֖זֶר כְּנֶגְדּֽוֹ׃ (יט) וַיִּצֶר֩ יְהוָ֨ה אֱלֹהִ֜ים מִן־הָֽאֲדָמָ֗ה כָּל־חַיַּ֤ת הַשָּׂדֶה֙ וְאֵת֙ כָּל־ע֣וֹף הַשָּׁמַ֔יִם וַיָּבֵא֙ אֶל־הָ֣אָדָ֔ם לִרְא֖וֹת מַה־יִּקְרָא־ל֑וֹ וְכֹל֩ אֲשֶׁ֨ר יִקְרָא־ל֧וֹ הָֽאָדָ֛ם נֶ֥פֶשׁ חַיָּ֖ה ה֥וּא שְׁמֽוֹ׃ (כ) וַיִּקְרָ֨א הָֽאָדָ֜ם שֵׁמ֗וֹת לְכָל־הַבְּהֵמָה֙ וּלְע֣וֹף הַשָּׁמַ֔יִם וּלְכֹ֖ל חַיַּ֣ת הַשָּׂדֶ֑ה וּלְאָדָ֕ם לֹֽא־מָצָ֥א עֵ֖זֶר כְּנֶגְדּֽוֹ׃ (כא) וַיַּפֵּל֩ יְהוָ֨ה אֱלֹהִ֧ים ׀ תַּרְדֵּמָ֛ה עַל־הָאָדָ֖ם וַיִּישָׁ֑ן וַיִּקַּ֗ח אַחַת֙ מִצַּלְעֹתָ֔יו וַיִּסְגֹּ֥ר בָּשָׂ֖ר תַּחְתֶּֽנָּה׃ (כב) וַיִּבֶן֩ יְהוָ֨ה אֱלֹהִ֧ים ׀ אֶֽת־הַצֵּלָ֛ע אֲשֶׁר־לָקַ֥ח מִן־הָֽאָדָ֖ם לְאִשָּׁ֑ה וַיְבִאֶ֖הָ אֶל־הָֽאָדָֽם׃ (כג) וַיֹּאמֶר֮ הָֽאָדָם֒ זֹ֣את הַפַּ֗עַם עֶ֚צֶם מֵֽעֲצָמַ֔י וּבָשָׂ֖ר מִבְּשָׂרִ֑י לְזֹאת֙ יִקָּרֵ֣א אִשָּׁ֔ה כִּ֥י מֵאִ֖ישׁ לֻֽקֳחָה־זֹּֽאת׃ (כד) עַל־כֵּן֙ יַֽעֲזָב־אִ֔ישׁ אֶת־אָבִ֖יו וְאֶת־אִמּ֑וֹ וְדָבַ֣ק בְּאִשְׁתּ֔וֹ וְהָי֖וּ לְבָשָׂ֥ר אֶחָֽד׃ (כה) וַיִּֽהְי֤וּ שְׁנֵיהֶם֙ עֲרוּמִּ֔ים הָֽאָדָ֖ם וְאִשְׁתּ֑וֹ וְלֹ֖א יִתְבֹּשָֽׁשׁוּ׃
ג
(א) וְהַנָּחָשׁ֙ הָיָ֣ה עָר֔וּם מִכֹּל֙ חַיַּ֣ת הַשָּׂדֶ֔ה אֲשֶׁ֥ר עָשָׂ֖ה יְהוָ֣ה אֱלֹהִ֑ים וַיֹּ֙אמֶר֙ אֶל־הָ֣אִשָּׁ֔ה אַ֚ף כִּֽי־אָמַ֣ר אֱלֹהִ֔ים לֹ֣א תֹֽאכְל֔וּ מִכֹּ֖ל עֵ֥ץ הַגָּֽן׃ (ב) וַתֹּ֥אמֶר הָֽאִשָּׁ֖ה אֶל־הַנָּחָ֑שׁ מִפְּרִ֥י עֵֽץ־הַגָּ֖ן נֹאכֵֽל׃ (ג) וּמִפְּרִ֣י הָעֵץ֮ אֲשֶׁ֣ר בְּתוֹךְ־הַגָּן֒ אָמַ֣ר אֱלֹהִ֗ים לֹ֤א תֹֽאכְלוּ֙ מִמֶּ֔נּוּ וְלֹ֥א תִגְּע֖וּ בּ֑וֹ פֶּן־תְּמֻתֽוּן׃ (ד) וַיֹּ֥אמֶר הַנָּחָ֖שׁ אֶל־הָֽאִשָּׁ֑ה לֹֽא־מ֖וֹת תְּמֻתֽוּן׃ (ה) כִּ֚י יֹדֵ֣עַ אֱלֹהִ֔ים כִּ֗י בְּיוֹם֙ אֲכָלְכֶ֣ם מִמֶּ֔נּוּ וְנִפְקְח֖וּ עֵֽינֵיכֶ֑ם וִהְיִיתֶם֙ כֵּֽאלֹהִ֔ים יֹדְעֵ֖י ט֥וֹב וָרָֽע׃ (ו) וַתֵּ֣רֶא הָֽאִשָּׁ֡ה כִּ֣י טוֹב֩ הָעֵ֨ץ לְמַאֲכָ֜ל וְכִ֧י תַֽאֲוָה־ה֣וּא לָעֵינַ֗יִם וְנֶחְמָ֤ד הָעֵץ֙ לְהַשְׂכִּ֔יל וַתִּקַּ֥ח מִפִּרְי֖וֹ וַתֹּאכַ֑ל וַתִּתֵּ֧ן גַּם־לְאִישָׁ֛הּ עִמָּ֖הּ וַיֹּאכַֽל׃ (ז) וַתִּפָּקַ֙חְנָה֙ עֵינֵ֣י שְׁנֵיהֶ֔ם וַיֵּ֣דְע֔וּ כִּ֥י עֵֽירֻמִּ

119920831.review: I love this game. The gameplay is super fun, the style of the game is extremely unique and fun, the plot is very original and the dialogue is absolutely hilarious. This is one of the most fun games I've ever played and I would seriously recommend picking it up.

119906828.review: Sure it's a little rough around the edges, but the level design and characters are good enough that you won't mind. Psychonauts is a unique experience that shouldn't be missed, especially now with the sequel out.

119905039.review:
Psychonauts is one of the most unique and entertaining games I've ever played. It has such a wonderful set of characters and locations, brimming with personality and life, and some fantastic upgrades and controls that makes the game a no-brainer (hehe) for anyone who enjoys a good 3D platformer. Oh yeah, AMAZING music.

My only critiques are that I did find the last few worlds to be a bit less polished than the earlier stages, and the item wheel, while fun, did lead to some clunky moments. The Dowsing Rod is an upgrade that I just couldn't get a feel for, and had to look up maps on how to find more Arrowheads.

My biggest issue was that I was playing on keyboard. If you can, please get a controller and play it with that, as keyboard and mouse makes some powers like Telekinesis more annoying to use (unless you map it to the mouse).

119657708.review:
Se trata de un juego de aventuras con plataformas. Lo mas interesante no son las habilidades "psíquicas" o las plataformas (las cuales no son todo lo precisas que deberían) sino sus mundos. Dado que los mundos son representaciones subconscientes de diferentes personas se siente únicos y con mucha personalidad, cada mundo tiene una "temática" pero al margen de eso tanto enemigos como npc poseen personalidades muy diferentes y acordes al tema del subconsciente.
Es muy entretenido aunque está en ingles tanto texto como voces aunque creo que hay una traducción para los textos, diría que es recomendable jugarlo antes del 2. 
Al escribir esta reseña no he jugado a la secuela pero tengo ganas porque como tiene muchos años de diferencia los mundos pueden ser aún mas únicos e interesantes con la tecnología actual.

119531032.review: Psychonauts is one of the greatest games ever made. I 101% completed this game for the second time, (originally did on PS2) and even on PS2 which is the worse version I still loved it to death. This is the definitive version of Psychonauts here though and every issue I had with the PS2 version was fixed here. This game deserves more love and attention, especially when it's only $9.99 for one of the greatest gaming experiences ever. Amazing story, amazing gameplay, 10/10.

119503321.review:
A very fun game and one of the only 3D platformers I've played that can actually compete with Mario. Psychonauts does not really innovate the genre but it tells fun and dark story that is about the mind that engages the mind. The levels are really charming and very creative, It can tell a story through level design alone. It adds comedy to mental illness while making them not full on jokes, it allows you to sympathize for them since you see what they see. Psychonauts was truly ahead of its time and it's only 6 dollars.

I give this game a BIG 3.5/5

119132680.review:
Me cayó de regalo hace ya como 10 años casi. Lo jugué por primera vez hace 8 años y lo pude terminar hace poco, debido a problemas técnicos. Pero me encanta este juego y se lo recomiendo a todo el mundo.

Eres Raz y te has colado en el campamento de verano de Psiconautas porque Raz es un friki de los Psiconautas y quiere convertirse en uno, aunque sea escapando de su familia.

Te vas colando en las mentes de los personajes para avanzar en la trama, y en estos niveles debes afrontar los problemas mentales del personaje y finalmente curarles la mente.

Usas tus poderes psíquicos para luchar y explorar. Tienes segmentos de acción y de plataformas. Y a mi lo que más me gusta de este tipo de juegos, la exploración es divertidísima porque vas descubriendo nuevos caminos y habitaciones ocultas, secretos... El juego ofrece muchos desafíos: encontrar objetos ocultos, coleccionar cartas PSI para aumentar nuestro rango de Psiconauta, entre otros.

Y la guinda del pastel para mi es su guión/humor. El juego no se toma en serio a sí mismo y siempre aprovecha cualquier oportunidad para meter bromas y chistes absurdos que le dan mucha gracia.

La próxima vez que lo juegue me lo completo al 100% porque mira me hace gracia.

119061599.review: I've only played this game for a few hours so far, but after a glowing review from a friend, I wanted to try it out and see if it was really as good as they said. Turns out, there's a lot more here than I expected, especially for an older game. The dialogue is very well written, often to the point of being absurdly hilarious, and the backstory behind the characters is great. The gameplay is actually challenging (but in a way where you want to try to beat it) and it's designed very creatively. I have a feeling it might become one of my new favorites!

119059519.review:
One of the most creative platformers i've ever played, a blast from start to.... the last level

That last level isn't that hard once you figure out what to do but that doesn't change the fact it's not very fun and the difficulty spike is pretty huge for a first time player

Don't let that deter you though, overall the game has aged incredibly well in graphics and writing, and the platforming, while sometimes a bit janky, is still a ton of fun and the unique level themes and psychic powers and puzzles makes for some incredible levels

If you haven't played this game yet you're definitely missing out, it's only 10 dollars so there's really no reason not to try it

A wonderfully charming platformer. Despite being presented like a kid's game, there are some surprisingly heavy themes in this game including suicide. Some of the early levels are just okay, but the later levels are all great. In those, you enter the minds of insane people to (attempt to) resolve their mental issues. I also laughed more playing this game than I have in a while. I can't tell if it's because it's great, or if it's just unique enough, or both. 

Overall I highly recommend this game. There aren't any 3D platformers I can think of that are quite like this.

Charming and child-like, but more adult than you'd think.  7/10
The cast brings nostalgic childish fun while the subject matter and stories that each level brings puts into perspective how mental health and trauma is not new.  Released in the early to mid-2000s, I'm glad this game exists and that it has a sequel in the more mental health-conscious present.

On a personal level I loved Persona 5 and exploring cognitions and trauma in a visualized way, so it was a charm to go into each level and figure these people out.  
Gameplay-wise, it's not my thing.  I don't generally like platforming and this game has some weird geometry in some areas making movement mildly maddening.  Also, some levels ask you to do moves that are only technically possible if you finaggle the controls to make a very specific turn in mid-air, which I did not expect to be expected of the player to perform.  Also not a completionist but do appreciate the collectibles; big fan of the safes that tell past stories of the person whose mind we're in.

In conclusion: I am the milkman. My milk is delicious. Go play this classic already!

117836944.review:
Psychonauts is an amazing game that has held up really well despite being released in 2005. I think the artstyle is very unique and looks great today when the resolution is scaled to current monitor sizes. Each level is extremely memorable, creative, fun to play, and the powers you unlock open up different ways to approach the levels. The soundtrack composed for this game is out-of-this-world and really immerses you in the world Double Fine have created. The humor in this game is great, which in combination with a compelling story and well written characters makes you not want to put your controller down while playing.

Speaking of controllers, I have beat this game twice, first with keyboard + mouse and the second time with a controller. If you have the option, I highly recommend using a controller, even as someone who prefers keyboard + mouse most of the time. Switching between psychic powers, navigating menus, and especially the platforming is much easier with a controller. Challenges I faced with mouse + keyboard like the punching mini game and the infuriatingly difficult meat circus level were not a problem at all when I used a controller.

To summarize, this game is absolutely worth it, sale or not. It's currently on sale for $2.50, which is a steal for a game that really isn't like any other game out there.

117311781.review:
I was one of the few people who bought Psychonauts on release. I liked it quite a bit, and yet found it a slightly disappointing narrative relative to Grim Fandango, even though it’s a better and more enjoyable game. Part of this was simply that I was never that into platformers, and part of it was that the game felt lightweight; it’s very much working within the summer-camp-movie genre, and lacks the pathos that Full Throttle and Grim Fandango channeled so well.

In 2021, I replayed it with a friend (who struggles with platformers) in preparation for Psychonauts 2, and I liked it more than I did the first time around. The art style has aged wonderfully—this is probably the best-looking Xbox game there is, precisely because it avoids graphical realism. This was also one of the last prominent “character platforms” outside of Mario, and so the gameplay felt fresher than it did when it was released. More than anything, I appreciated just how ambitious the game was, how each level substantially changed the formula, how it seems to have a faith that its audience will go along with a lot of weirdness as long as it’s charming and well-executed. And it is: in fact, the levels probably get better as the game goes on. There are a million retrospective odes to The Milkman Conspiracy, but while it’s a great level I don’t think it stands head and shoulds above the rest, and it isn’t even my favorite (that would either be Lungfishopolis or Waterloo World). And what I saw as slightness back then, I now see as a light touch, an excellent genre ode that is full of delightful characters who are fun to spend time with.

Psychonauts isn’t a game that needed a sequel—a last-minute cliffhanger aside, it’s wonderfully self-contained and does everything it needs to—but it certainly deserved one, and I’m heartened it found a bigger audience in the years after its release.
