116518058.review:
[b]My Playtime:[/b] 24.7h (36/37 achievement, finished the game)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (27 achievements, 5+ are missable).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Psychonauts[/b] is a mix of adventure and precision platformer in a world where psychic power exists. You'll dive into several minds, traversing through the platforming sections and defeating a boss while utilizing your psychic skills.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- A lot of collectibles to get
- Unique boss fights that require a certain strategy to beat

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Camera can auto-rotate right after you are jumping
- Platforming sections can be problematic due to the mechanics

[b]Specs[/b]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you don't mind the tricky platforming sections and want to enjoy a unique game, buy this game.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
In case you didn't notice, the game was released in 2005. It should be obvious that the graphics have aged here. Characters look weird because of their low-poly models and cutscenes are blurred. Some of the in-game scenes might not look as blurry, but they still aren't as sharp as in recent games. That being said, I liked the game's theme. Dungeons feel unique since you are exploring a person's mind instead of a natural environment. Expect to see surreal and bizarre occurrences that are caused by the chaos in the person's mind.

[h3]Story[/h3]
The story follows Raz, a boy that runs from his home to learn how to use his psychic powers in a summer camp. You'll get to know other people who are joining the camp, whether it's about their love interests or hobbies. Everyone is carefully designed, giving details to their character from your conversations or their personalities. That being said, the details are as shallow as they can be; you can see that they only have one thing in their mind, and that's what's good about it. The game never forgets to make a cutscene that showcases this trait.

The main story is unpredictable. Besides the predictable part when you have to explore someone's mind in the end, the story never has a set goal except for Raz to learn as much power as he can before his time at the camp ends. The story isn't revolved to keep the story mysterious for a twist, but it's still fun to see the interaction between the characters. It's a kind of story that will get you immersed because you enjoy the worldbuilding so much, especially because of how silly the characters are.

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
As I said before, the game is a mix of adventure and precision platformer. You can explore the camping grounds, traversing through the platforming sections with your psychic ability to get the collectibles. The game is also a part collecthathon, forcing you to collect a lot of objects, both in the real world and in the mental world, to increase your psychic skills. You'll explore a lot of dungeons, all with a unique theme, where you have to follow the rules to finish. Although most of them are as straightforward as clearing the dungeon, others can be more unique, requiring you to either collect certain key items, move a pawn in a board, and others.

Platforming sections are tricky. You need to do acrobatic skills like walking on a rope and using a trapeze to jump. The thing is, it's hard to measure the depth between the rope and your position, making it hard to figure out where you need to land. You need to do trial and error several times to figure out how to jump properly, and this can cause another problem when you are pressed with time or had a long way back up if you fail the jump. As for the trapeze, it can take a while before you figure out how to use them effectively - I thought that I only need to hold a key in one direction to gain momentum, but it turns out that you need to move back and forth to do so. Moreover, jumping also can be tricky in some places. There are many times when you can't do a double jump if you are not doing it fast enough. Although it doesn't cause many issues in earlier dungeons, the very last dungeon becomes so problematic to finish because of them, especially since you need to traverse the area within a time limit.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2345562054

Collectibles are abundant. Some might even be placed in the trickiest places that you can imagine, requiring you to utilize your platforming skills. You'll need to redo some areas several times to get some collectibles, but it will be worth it in the end, especially since it will reward you with upgrades. To be honest, I don't think I will be able to finish the last dungeon without some upgrades.

Boss fights are unique. As you can see, each dungeon has a unique theme that is related to what the target cares about. Someone obsessed with art will have a gallery-themed world, while someone obsessed with a party will also have a party in their mind, and the same also applies to boss fights. Unlike other games, you don't have to spam your attack button to hit the enemy - you need to figure out how to beat them first. This will use your psychic powers somehow, both direct and indirect. You might need to fly to a certain place that allows you to beat the boss, or throw an object to hurt them directly. Each boss has a different weak point to exploit, so you need to learn their weakness as soon as you can. However, the game won't give any hints to beat them save for a few bosses, and you might get stuck in a boss fight if you don't figure out a way to hurt them soon.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2814448390

[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
I finished the game in 24.7h, but I admit that I left the game open from time to time since I was also doing other tasks. The game has some annoying platforming sections, one that requires you to retry the same areas over and over if you fail. The thing is, you won't respawn in the same area as where you died - instead, you'll respawn in a certain checkpoint. There is a chance that you need to redo some areas that you have cleared several times because you didn't manage to finish the next one.

[b]Others[/b]
The camera movement is annoying in the last dungeon. The game will rotate the camera around automatically, and this might happen when you are jumping, making it easy to fall on the ground.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Although the graphics have aged, [b]Psychonauts[/b] is still enjoyable as it is. The concept of exploring human minds is unique, and boss fights always feel different due to their theme. The platforming section might need some work, especially on the camera and mechanics, but it's good enough as it is. If you like adventure games with platforming elements and want to try out new things, be sure to play this game.

My biggest complain honestly is wanting more content so now I'm heavily debating buying Psychonauts 2 whenever it goes on sale or even buying game pass ultimate for a month to play it.

116058592.review:
Psychonauts is a masterpiece of 3D platforming, and is an instant recommendation for me.

However, it is not in a playable state on Linux. Attempting to use Proton compatibility layers causes the boot-up logo screens to bug out, forcing the game to be exited. The native version is smooth for 95% of the game--but it is the other 5% that I have a problem with. The game starts in a windowed mode, does not accept controller input normally, and when trying to make it full-screen, does not have the cursor's position line up with what the cursor is selecting, resulting in a guessing game of where the cursor needs to be to select something in the options. The game grinds to a halt when it has to render in footsteps on snow, sand, etc., which makes the first level's portion which features snow incredibly slow. (An observation about this is that sometimes the graphics would glitch out and create a wide square of footprint patterns, which ironically solves the problem of the footsteps). This makes the soldier-killing and tank-approaching sections very tedious. The final boss is completely unplayable, as it literally progresses at about 1 frame per second, even when the graphical quality is at its lowest setting. I can run Ori and the Will of the Wisps on this computer at 1080p 120fps with no problems, yet a game made 16 years ago can't stop chugging in certain sections of the game.

I had to watch the final part of this game on YouTube, which is never something that I want to have to do. Fortunately, this game was $1 on sale and I think that I did in fact get more than my money's worth, even if I had bought it at the full $10. That being said, a game which is supposed to "perform well" on the Steam Deck and isn't Verified only because of some icons not being exact, should be performing just fine on a computer and system designed for gaming. 

Please implement a fix for this, or please state somewhere that this game is not yet ready for a full Linux experience.

Edit: Psychonauts 2 runs perfectly on my Linux setup using Proton v8--not even a single frame drop or stutter anywhere! If there's anyone out there from Double Fine reading this, consider my post as support for a potential Psychonauts 1 remaster (as unlikely as that is, obviously).

115822847.review:
Psychonauts is a 3D platformer where you play as a young rapscallion named Rasputin who’s managed to sneak their way into a camp for children to hone their psychic powers under the guidance of mental professionals known as Psychonauts. And Psychonauts is a fucking ass video game. I can not in good conscience suggest Psychonauts to anyone without some serious caveats 

First, the GOOD:

Psychonauts visuals and style are the forefront and man are they really the best part of this game. The varied environments of people’s mindscapes, from a men in black riddled suburbia to a neon fluorescent Spanish decorated street front, every single mind you step into as a psychonaut is visual bliss. Some are stronger than others in their presentation but it's undeniable the amount of effort and charm put into these environments to not only make them functional but also interesting to look at and play in. Each environment or I guess “level” lends it self so well to the inclusion of gameplay because while it may be slightly varied from what previously was faced, its almost always utilizing something unique to that person’s psyche. Its fun.

Story too. Surprisingly enough, I found the writing to be a serious highlight. It never felt forced or like it was trying to make me laugh. It always managed to surprise me in the weirdest ways. WHether it was idle dialogue from fellow campers or Rasputin spouting some of his rambling nonsense when he found a clue or got confused. Little stuff that managed to charm me enough to care about the characters and what was going on.

Now the BAD, and the UGLY:

Psychonauts to its very core is an extremely clunky game. I chose to use a controller for ym play through. SO often i found myself glitching out on geometry during platforming, or getting just too high up on a pole to get shot off and have to climb all the way back up. Or maybe I'd be climbing on a  wall and the game wouldn’t let me prompt a double jump so I fell down however far just to redo a heaping sshit ton of platforming and climbing i just barely managed to scrape by 15 minutes ago. Other times because of the lack of guidance (which was actually mostly welcome) I had ZERO CLUE where I was meant to go, and either had to look up a fucking IGN tutorial (yuck) or finesse my  way over an obstacle by way of elaborate parkour, that I know for certain was not the way i was meant to progress! Combat too was an anomaly. I know that it was mostly my end but combat behaves in such a weird clunky and bad way. One trigger is meant to lock on while the other lets you shoot or use an ability, but so often i’d be just out of reach of what i wanted to hit the game wouldn’t lock on and instead turn my camera so i’m facing the other way!?? I’m sure there’s more i’ve forgotten to mention here but that’s just a handful of stuff that really got me cleaving for the gun in my drawer.

Psychonauts is a really tough game to love, and I'm sure the ones who do are honest fans who can overlook the flaws and enjoy a fun time in an interesting universe. As for me, as much as i enjoyed it, there was just too much that ruined the experience for me. And with the sequel getting such great reviews and not requiring a pass on this game to understand, AND a serious visual uplift taboot, I’d have to say for this game, you should absolutely pass it up for the sequel.

115487571.review:
I loved this game when I first played it on the Xbox and my feelings about it remain the same even though I experienced some gameplay issues and bugs. 

Although the game came out in the mid 2000s, it still looks pretty good.  The cartoony aesthetics keep the graphics from getting too dated, though you can definitely tell it's an older game.  

The music is just as fantastic as I remember it being.  I especially love the Meat Circus theme.  If you like Danny Elfman/Star Wars type music you will probably enjoy this.  

The best part of the game is the writing.  While the overall story is pretty simple, the stories you uncover inside each levels are great, especially the one involving the Milkman character.  While Psychonauts is meant to be a humorous game,  it does delve into darker areas at times.  The blend of these moods is what makes the story so appealing.  

The level design is some of the most creative I've ever seen.  Each one really emphasizes the personalities of the characters' minds you enter.  

The gameplay is decent enough to be enjoyable, but it does have some problems.  For starters, telekinesis can be a pain to use sometimes, so most of the time I would stick with PSI blast if I could get away with it.  Sliding on rails is also clunky because I've gotten stuck a couple of times and it's easy to fall to your death when that happens.  The powers are mostly useful, though there are a few that are situational.  Lastly, there is a lot of collecting to do, and while I enjoy that, some of the figments can be a real ball ache to collect because they blend into the scenery and are in difficult to reach areas.  

I also ran into a save breaking bug.  I sped through the dialogue through the first shooting level and I ended up breaking progression and resetting didn't fix it.  I also got stuck into a wall once.  At least I didn't have any crashing issues.  

The difficulty isn't too hard.  I'd say it's one of the easier platformers out there, but it's still enjoyable for the reasons I mentioned earlier.  

This game totally deserves to be a classic and I highly recommend it.

For as much as I adore [spoiler]the Milkman Conspiracy[/spoiler], it's a little obtuse at times and the amount of time spent fumbling around trying to find out where to go causes the level to drag a little bit.

115030714.review:
[h1] Steam Deck / Pop!_OS(Linux) & 4K User Review [/h1]

Man where do I even begin..

[b]i am not saying don't buy the game[/b], just my experience so fare just setting it up has been less to be desired as a Linux User, so this is going to be relatively short and to the point because most of my playtime at the point of review has been me literally troubleshooting the game to get it to function in a manner that is predictable & reliable.

This game unbeknownst to me has a Native Linux application(GG, Microsoft or I guess just DoubleFine). It well.. Started & I was immediately met with a 800x600 resolution. With that said the game is 17yrs old+, so that's not really a problem. The problem is that my mouse literally could not select options in the menu even if hovering directly over them & I had to do some hovering voodoo to get get what I wanted highlighted which was like a solid 15-30min already.

I get 2160p enabled & from that point things work within a tolerable range, menu icons still have issues highlighting, but the menu scaled relatively & thus no voodoo was required. It did detect controller inputs, but that was the least of my worries. [b]Said button prompts were pretty ancient using only numbers instead of Standard ABXY[/b]. So I spent time configuring the setup to what seemed appropriate for the game.

[h1]Extra 15-25min.[/h1]

Cool, I play through to the training camp where they teach you how to play the game, Button prompts don't even show in the numbers of old you just configured, they still show the key bindings. Regardless I made a discovery & that is that R2/RightTriggger is not binned to anything to my limited knowledge & if you try to assign it a key or use it while the program is open, you'll encounter [b]a dreaded camera angle bug where it will act as if you are inputting the camera in any which or one specific direction hindering gameplay & making the game unplayable imo.[/b]

I start troubleshooting accordingly & long behold.. I'm actually using the Linux Native version of the game. Wow, I see why Valve originally did not care to test Linux builds for games. The experience varies and can often depending on the game, [b]offer subpar quality compared to using the .exe + Proton.[/b]

Switching over to Proton Experimental solved Menu issues, so now using my key/mouse requires zero thought, just do.

[h1]Cloud Saves do not automatically work with the Linux Build of Psychonauts[/h1]

I'm actually dumbfounded by this one, maybe they use different ways to save the game, this is a Linux build from 2005, but Steam didn't even try to save the file. [b]I'm actually speechless[/b], I either don't know enough to form an opinion or Valve just didn't offer Cloud Saves for that particular build for some reason. I did have space for the save but it showed as 0 kbp written despite .04 kbps being available.

[h1] Controller is not detected with Proton [/h1]

The icing on the cake.

On-top of not having my save files so I have to start from scratch(I barely finished training, so not a big deal), redo all of my settings & then [b]I have to manually EDIT my controller layout to effectively use Keyboard Inputs[/b], when I barely have any idea of a good profile for the game due to its out of date button prompts.

[h1]DoubleFine should just remake Psychonauts & pull this version.[/h1]

With them investing so much in Psychonauts 2 & the success it has been, i'm shocked they haven't atleast considered it; publicly.

So yeah my first 2hrs have been me basically setting up the game. This review does not reflect on the game's story, merely flaws in it's Linux/Windows builds for Proton users.

[b]TL;DR / / If you're using the Linux build do NOT press R2/RightTrigger, you know what. Outright abandon the Linux Build and just use Proton Experimental, it's more reliable. If you do use proton, you'll need to setup a custom controller config to the key bindings if your controller is not detected in-game.[/b]

[b]I'll probably release a Community Controller Layout, and call it "Unplayable Psychonauts: Controller Fix". Because honestly trying to run this game was more trouble than it was worth.[/b]

I'm sure it's a fine game, but this basically robbed me of my time before work, spent [b]basically not having fun.[/b]

114361207.review:
Is this a perfect game? No— there are many flaws. However, the idea, the pure essence of the game is so endearing and well executed, that I think it's worth looking past its issues.

[b]So, why is it a good game?[/b]

 Maneuverability is [i]very[/i] fun. The levitation power carries the gameplay hands down. You basically get a ball that rolls on slopes, increases your jump height, and allows you to glide; this drastically changes the pace of the game, and allows you to experiment and zoom through many sections of the game.

Many games have very generic areas, where it's a forest, maybe some plains, a castle. Psychonauts just goes wild; each level is a character's mind, and not everyone is mentally stable. So what happens when you have a man whose lost his mind and is battling whether he thinks he's Napoleon or not? You end up playing as a piece in Catan, fighting for this guy's sanity. It's less the moment to moment gameplay that stands out, but the thematic storytelling that really sells all of the locations.

The overall style of the game is also very nice; the artstyle complements the humor, and it's good enough to delve into mental health while staying humorous but (sometimes) serious.

[b]So what sucks?[/b] The grind for currency at one point to actually progress, the boss sequences (especially the ending) feel off, the lack of common sense in some puzzles, the bland hub world, and the bore of completionism,

The puzzle design in Psychonauts is a bit all over the place. For example, there's a puzzle that requires you to look through the bird's view, and then go through a tiny gate so that another gate will open. Is there any indication that that's what you're supposed to do? No. There [i]is[/i] a tip system included in the game, which comes in handy, but it feels bad when you don't even see how it makes much sense.

The hub world is lackluster; you're jumping into these awesome levels that are super unique... and then you're in a forest with one real building that's just a log cabin. It feels disconnected in a way that threw me off early in the game; don't expect the kind of exploration in the hub to be much like the levels, because they are quite different in how they functionally play.

For completionists, there are many missable achievements and collectibles. You definitely need a guide to make sure you don't miss anything in the game. Along with that, there are many "figments" or pictures in every level (100-200) that are just scattered absolutely everywhere, and there's so little reward/guidance that it never felt good collecting. 

If you can, definitely play this game with a controller. I played with keyboard and mouse, and it was kinda difficult to use not because it was non functional, but because it just felt slightly off— it certainly was not designed for it.

[b]So, should you play Psychonauts?[/b] If you like platformers, yes. There's enough charm in the game to make it worth your while.

I love this game and everyone should give it a try, that's all that needs to be said really. 

But to expound on that a little more I'll say this, this game is close to twenty years old now and still nothing is like it, not even it's sequel. It's story, characters and gameplay are so unique that it's hard to compare it to any other game. Psychonauts came out around the time where platformers were still a huge genre and at the I ignored this game because of that. Barring Mario 64, Banjo Kazooie and maybe a few others the platforming genre was one that became almost instantly stale; boring collect a-thons, lame anthropomorphic characters, jarring color palates and storylines seemingly taken from children's cartoons (which I guess makes sense since these games were aimed at children). But Psychonauts has a more serious (and sometimes funny) story that deals with mental illness, super unique and varied worlds to explore and collecting thats more reigned in.

It's not perfect of course, some of platforming (Meat Circus) is really dated and had me frustrated but it's nothing that brings the game down overall. I was able to 100% this game and enjoy it throughout.

So if anyone reading this is on the fence about whether to get the game I say take the plunge, it's well, well worth it!

For anyone that has an affinity for unique 3D platformers and a moderate tolerance for early-3D gaming jank, I can only highly recommend Psychonauts. Every level offers its own unique gameplay elements while also providing a story behind the individual’s mind that you’ve hopped into. The main protagonist, Raz, is surrounded by a memorable cast that are backed up by their humorous and witty dialogue. In many ways, this game exceeds its contemporaries in the genre with a less grounded approach and it is worth playing for that reason alone.

A word of warning - Psychonauts is a product of its time and suffers some issues that may bother players accustomed to modern gaming experiences: the game is littered with loading screens, the 8 PSI-power have to annoyingly be managed among 3 buttons, the cutscenes are low-quality, pre-rendered video which clash heavily with the real-time rendered visuals, and in general, the game doesn’t have the smooth control of a modern game.

If you can get past these issues then you will be rewarded with one of the most memorable games in the last 20 years.

113296834.review:
[i]Psychonauts[/i] is an offbeat adventure game. Utilizing psychic powers to plunge into crazed minds and solve their mental traumas, this game is a dark children's game with a lot of nostalgia to offer older players too. A progressive power-up system tied to collectibles rewards explorative and repeat play, while the zany cast and striking design will keep you pining for more. The game does have some weaker levels and aged graphics, but if you're in the mood to try an indie classic than check this out.

You play as Raz, a young prodigy attending a summer camp to train kids in the basics of psychic warfare, in the hopes of becoming a titular Psychonaut. To do so, Raz must earn merit badges demonstrating his skill in an array of psychic abilities useful to combat and mobility. All the while, he must get to know a quirky cast of fellow campers and adult teachers, all the while uncovering a sinister conspiracy underfoot at the camp...

[i]Psychonauts[/i] brims with delightful, chaotic energy. The game's looks apply Tim Burton's aesthetic to different classic dark cartoons like [i]Invader Zim[/i] or [i]The Grim Adventures of Billy & Mandy[/i], and the writing follows in that stead. This title plays out like a kid's cartoon, complete with simple dialogue, inscrutable adult characters, and basic humor you'd find in any Nicktoon - it just so happens that the premise twists all of that into a unintentional self-parody of the genre that adult players may find nostalgic amusement within.

Gameplay largely consists of platforming, with some minor combat and exploration elements. Each "level" involves delving into a character's mind, with the enemies and obstacles all representations of their psychological trauma. Raz can employ additional psychic powers that he learns over time to help overcome obstacles, and often there are multiple paths forward allowing for mandatory or optional abilities to be used, ensuring players who invest time to power themselves up feel rewarded. Levels also contain a ton of collectibles, each important either by providing opportunities to share backstories or further upgrade the player, greatly incentivizing careful exploration and multiple replays.

[i]Psychonauts[/i] does show its age in a few places. The graphics are closer to [i]Super Mario 64[/i] than modern AAA standard, though it does help the game feel in place with its generation of animated works like [i]Monster House[/i]. The many powers available to use can also at times leave players unsure of how to proceed through the game's puzzling levels - some particularly combine this with tight, unforgiving platforming to make for an annoying experience (lookin' at you, a certain history-themed level). Fortunately the good outweighs the bad of the levels, and there are a number in here that make for iconic, memorable experiences.

This game permeates with what I can best describe as an aura of "carnival madness." The variety of levels and themes at play makes this a worthwhile purchase alone, though the simple-yet-clever writing really seals the deal. Get psyched already and report to Basic Braining, stat! [i]Psychonauts[/i] gets an A-.

113254084.review:
Pretty fun game but it doesn't work well on new hardware. You have to do changes in files and install modifications if you want it to work. Bellow are ways to help you have a good time. 


You can find much help from PCGamingWiki: https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Psychonauts

In the settings of the game (for some reason you cannot change these in the main menu) you should disable Vsync. There is also mouse acceleration that you cannot disable. Also limit your FPS to 60 otherwise you will have some issues like opennig doors and so forth. 
The things I had problems with to start with is the resolution. To fix this you can download the Widescreen fix from here: https://thirteenag.github.io/wfp#psychonauts

I also had problems with the game crashing. What worked for me was setting the compatability mode to Windows 95. You can do this by right clicking the .exe you find in the install folder and choose properties. From there you tick "Run this program in compatability mode for" and choose "windows 95". 

Hope you enjoy the game!

112571129.review:
Man, what an absolutely FANTASTIC game.

Once again this is one of those games that I had in my queue for YEARS and just now decided to install it to check it out. I am amazed by what I found out. I can't properly describe how great this one is. 

-The whole premise is original and the game pushes it as much as it can. What starts fairly straightforward unfolds into several twist and turns that engage you from the go.
-The graphics are weird but don't fall into "ugly" territory. It even makes some of the mind sequences memorable. It's unique in a very good way
-The characters and dialogue are great. There's a case to say that, if you don't divert from the main path you won't interact with some of them and you won't really care for them by the end but if you stop in between missions and walk around to meet them you'll get good conversations and laughs out of them
-The combat and powerups are on point. You're never overpowered and you'll find usage for everything in your arsenal
-The approach to the mental issues some of the characters have is incredible. Trauma, nightmares, personality disorder... Every mind you visit is unique but has layers of secrets and privacy that makes you rethink everything you're seeing and what you thought about the people they belong to. There's a "cute" feeling towards the graphics but some of the things you discover can get quite dark
-All the levels are original and fantastic. No two of them are the same and some, like the Milkman level, will stay with you for one reason or another

The only complain that I'll say about the game is that I'm not a fan of the camera. It's one of those that's mostly very close to your back and I prefer it to be a little farther away to better see my surroundings. In some specific parts where there's some precise platforming I got frustrated a couple of times but overall doesn't hurt the whole experience

All in all I'm speechless about this one. Probably the best gaming experience I've had this year so far

112159929.review: I really enjoy the fact that Psychonauts never makes fun of mental disorders or uses them for comedy or shock. All the characters are just people who experienced trauma or happened to experience mental health issues. Plus, it’s established that fixing these issues is difficult and nuanced. Raz gives the patients serious help in overcoming major obstacles, but it’s established that no one is just ‘cured’ one and done. The patients are now just able to care for themselves enough to move forward. You see this in Sasha and Milla’s minds as well. Sasha is healthy, but still has issues with repression. Milla has remaining trauma, but is coping with it in a healthy way. I think the main message of the game is that everyone has issues and empathy is important.

Very creative platformer that has unique levels, visuals, and boss fights.

The overall story is fantastic. It blends a somewhat dark psychic fantasy with themes of mental illness. The humor is similar to a cartoon that would air on nickelodeon in the 90s. A lot of the game will be spent literally inside of the minds of others. Teachers instruct you on psychic powers inside of their own heads while also unintentionally revealing their own inner struggles. People battling things like depression, creative blocks, paranoia, self doubt, and multiple personalities can be helped by entering their minds via a psychic doorway to help them fight their inner turmoil and clean up their mental cobwebs.

I used a controller and for the most part the game wasn't frustrating when it came to controlling my character. The camera can sometimes be a pain. The game is incredibly easy going. It even includes a feature where you can ask for help. So yeah not a very challenging game. Not every game needs to be though.

One play through and I got 19 hours out of it. I took my time, collected a lot, and found a few secrets. Didn't obsess over a 100%. I'll probably be back for another go of it at some point.

111110382.review:
[h1]Enter the Collective Unconsious[/h1]

It's a non-puzzle story-based platformer collectathon.

The core premise is that you are a Psychic Soldier who can project yourself into the minds of troubled personalities and cure their insanity. It's like if a Psychiatrist actually did something rather than keep asking you how something makes you feel. Now instead of throwing you into a menu where each level was someone's mind, you are put into a learning environment where you are trained on how to be a [i]Psychonaut[/i] and you enter people's minds by going to them in the real world and affixing a mini-door (the Psycho-Portal) on their forehead.

Instead of upgrading your abilities via a Skill Tree, you have a Skill Wheel where distinct powers can be added to your kit in the form of [i]Merit Badges[/i] like in Scouts. You earn these merit badges by completing each of the training courses, or by an overly complicated procedure of: [i]ranking up by collecting figments and cobwebs inside minds, collecting spinning cards and arrowheads from the real world, spending arrowheads to buy PSI cores in the camp lodge, then traveling to Ford's lair and using both machines at the bottom that serve the same purpose...[/i] and every couple of ranks, you get New Skills and upgrades to pre-existing skills just to avoid a skill tree.

In terms of platforming, there is:

[list]
    [*]Gliding from Breath of the Wild (the Levitation Balloon)
    [*]Ground Pound from Mario but with splash damage (Melee after a jump)
    [*]Double Jump to correct false distance judgement (Base Kit)
    [*]Moon Gravity Jumps (the Levitation Ball)
    [*]Climbing, Swinging, and Rail Grinding.
[/list]

However, there is clunk. For example, the rails can't properly figure out gravity and start pushing you randomly to either side. You just lose your grip randomly while climbing poles, swinging beams, grinding rails, etc and either fall off or start clipping awkwardly as you spam your jump button in order to fix it. 

The collectibles are very loosely tied to the core of the game. Figments are just supposed to be expressions that you'd perform whilst in the place it's meant to be collected (like a person climbing a ladder or playing music on stage) but these act more like guiding lines similar to the coins in Mario to show what way you need to go. Mental Cobwebs were honestly unnecessary and just gives you a purpose to revisit older levels after unlocking the 'Cobweb Duster' later down the line after grinding for Arrowheads by button mashing with a Dowsing Rod (another over-complicated system that just takes the focus out of the interesting part of the game (inside minds) and makes you waste time in the real world/ camp. So many collectibles are flat, you don't know how to get them properly cause they're literally invisible when viewed from the side especially since they're translucent too. The only good collectibles are the [b]Vaults[/b] because they show a summary of a person's happy moments and their divulgement into troubles in the form of caricature sketches.

The game makes you feel smart for playing it, unlike other brain-numbing games like Borderlands, and it does it without making the puzzles complex at all. When solving a puzzle, it emulates a feeling as if you've identified the crux of a person's mental issue and could relate to it in its creative expression. The art style may seem like an excuse for making imperfect models, but it fits the 'Caricature Nature' of it very well.
Mobility and offense aren't the only part of your kit because you also have puzzle-solving-centric abilities. But even though they work on a wide range of NPCs, they aren't as fleshed out as I thought they'd be (Invisibilty, Clairvoyance, Confusion, and Telekinesis)

Agent Cruller's bacon guides are useful and the fast travel system is super convenient because there's always a log when you need one.
it was not as painful to play as other older games like Half-Life as I did in the past because of its forward-thinking design.

I had trouble setting up my controller cause Steam Input wouldn't work from the get-go and kept detecting my keyboard as the primary input which the game kept defaulting to. There's a long opening cutscene and you can't change settings or resolution until then. The switch from QHD 160fps in-game graphics to SD 30fps cutscenes is quite jarring but at least they are in widescreen I guess... Flipping the camera makes the right joystick inverted in menu/selection wheels too (the left joystick is fine though).

[spoiler]When we normally enter someone's mind, we have to face censors that fight back against things that aren't supposed to be there, to prevent the mind from going into insanity or having weird thoughts. But in Boyd Cooper's mind, we see a complete lack of censors because his mind has been twisted by society and has placed him into a conspiracy-head, and the censors in his mind are fighting against himself to keep itself sane.[/spoiler] Some of the other levels I liked were [spoiler]Sasha's Shooting Gallery, Black Velvetopia, and Waterloo World[/spoiler] Unlike other levels, the collectibles actually helped me find the right path than disturb me.

110361563.review:
A fun game, and a classic from older console days. It works quite well on PC, and scales up to higher resolutions quite well - though the cutscenes and user-interface elements don't scale as well, it works.

You follow Razputin - a boy who ran away from the circus in order to fulfill his dream of becoming a Psychonaut. He arrives as a camp for gifted psychic children, which doubles as a recruiting place for the Psychonauts themselves. The Psychonauts fight with the power of psychic powers, using them to dive into the minds of others or to defeat them more conventionally.

The game therefore follows you as you basically explore the minds of a number of interesting cast members. You defeat their inner demons, and through that learn a great deal about the characters. Each world is unique and has unique mechanics, and the voice acting and characters are all very charming and fun.

The core gameplay is a platformer puzzler. Every boss and every area has puzzles that you must figure out to progress, and you gain new psychic powers - useful in specific ways - as you progress in the game. Strong enemies for example might be easily defeated by lighting them on fire, while the shield you gain later in the game can protect you from otherwise impossible to dodge abilities. The puzzles and such are not extremely difficult, but are challenging and fun - so definitely still engaging.

It took me around 11 hours to beat, and I ended at level 75 of about 100. If I wanted to 100% complete it, I probably would have needed about 15 hours and to have taken a bit more time to get all of the collectibles and such. It was fun for what it was, and I'm looking forward to playing the second one - it took long enough to release!

Definitely a game I want to come back and re-play sooner rather than later. The last time I completed this game was a good...10 years ago, or something along those lines. I struggled with a few of the bosses and mechanics, however I'm not sure if that's just because I was "bad" at games when I played it initially.

With the release of Psychonauts 2 - the re-awakening of this fandom & the first game itself has been awesome. 

This game - the first Psychonauts - has so much personality that even the few janky controls and weird boss mechanics makes you come crawling back for more. The characters are all so charming and funny! The story for the game itself is a little weak at times, more of just a "go here, do this, do that" especially on your first play-through if you aren't focusing on collectables.

The game is, and I continue to say this to this day, one of my favourite single player story games. It's dated, it's a little ugly, but the graphics work due to the heavy stylisation put into designs (characters, atmosphere, level) which I personally find to be a really interesting style. 

The visuals are gorgeous. I remember just running around in Black Velvetopia for hours on end just soaking in the colours and sounds & mechanics. Not ONLY are the visuals gorgeous, but so is the soundtrack and sound design itself! It's so..fun! Unique! It fits the game PERFECTLY. I CONSTANTLY have the campgrounds theme going on in my head.

I would definitely say this game is harder than the second one, if anyone is coming here from there, but it's mostly due to the more outdated and janky mechanics. But it's worth it, so entirely worth it. Iconic voice-acting, the oh-so frustrating follow/guide mission, beautiful visuals & sounds, and hilarious characters make it an overwhelmingly must-have experience.

109721851.review:
Gameplay: 8/10
Graphics: 7/10
Sound: 7/10
Story: 8/10
Replay/Value: 8/10

Overall: 7.6/10

109699312.review:
Psychonauts is a good game that truly shines in its ability to portray an interesting, quirky and diverse experience. Considered an underrated gem, Psychonauts delivers a unique experience for players while retaining many aspects of what make 3-D platformers fun.  While I agree with the notion that the game is underrated, I also believe that the game receives slightly more praise than it deserves. Let me break it down.

Story: 8/10

Story is simple, which is a good thing for this game. Not gonna spoil anything, but it has a lot of funny moments and quirky scenarios. The game understands itself well and knows that it doesn't need an intricate plot to provide an enjoyable tale to the player. The writing is probably the best part of the game, having some really crazy moments. 

Graphics: 8/10

Considering this came out in the PS2 era, the game's graphics are obviously outdated by today's standards. However, the art design behind the game is excellent and really fits the weird aesthetic the game delivers. During gameplay, the graphics are crisp and retain their cartoon-ish charm. Unfortunately, cutscenes are horribly rendered and look blurry, grainy and very unappealing at times. Other than this, the levels are colorful and creative, while the characters are funny and their looks fit their personality. I believe the game could have looked slightly better considering how small the game is, but overall, the graphics are great. 

Gameplay: 7/10

In terms of gameplay, Psychonauts is generally fun. There are many abilities and skills that you learn throughout the course of the game. You level up and gain new power-ups for your moves, giving you somewhat of a sense of character development. There are plenty of collectibles scattered around the map and some require certain moves to acquire them, much like Zelda games. Unfortunately, most of the moves are useless and you will probably only use the same 2 or 3 for the whole game. Another issue I have with the gameplay is just how clunky the platforming feels. Jumps feel delayed, and the lock-on feature is useless most of the time due to Raz's slow dodges. Some segments of the game can be quite annoying because of the inconsistencies in jumping and swinging. Luckily, with a bit of practice, it can be quite manageable. Another gripe about gameplay is the lack of information the games gives you about what you're supposed to do or where to go. There were many instances where I found myself wandering the map for a long time trying to find my next objective. There is a lot of trial and error, especially with certain bosses. The most annoying part of the game is the need to collect a currency called arrowheads to progress in one of the levels. I had 100 arrowheads by the time I realized that the game wanted me to buy an item for 800 before I could proceed. But the worst part was that I had to spend my 100 arrowheads to buy a different item that would let me find more arrowheads to then be able to buy the item I needed to continue the story. I actually almost uninstalled the game because it's ridiculous that I would have to stop what I'm doing, leave the level, and go on a crusade for 30 minutes finding more arrowheads. This happens again in another level where you have to buy paintings to continue the story. This was a horrible design choice since it ruins the flow of the game and wastes time. Overall, the gameplay is okay and can occasionally be fun but definitely expect to be lost and possibly looking at FAQ's to find out what to do. 

Sound: 9/10

Sounds are fantastic! Music is great, sound effects really suit the vibe of the game and the voice acting... is...AMAZING. Never expected such high quality voice acting in a game so old. Every single character is perfectly portrayed with excellent delivery from the voice actors. The only reason I'm giving it a 9/10 is because, for some reason, the game's audio stutters whenever I used headphones -- so I had to play using my computer's speakers. This is just my experience so I'm not sure if others share the same problem. 


Controls: 7.5/10

Controls are relatively fine. Moving around isn't too much of an issue since it plays much like most games of its kind. However, the UI is really annoying. Selecting the map, items and collectibles is extremely cumbersome and takes more time than it needs to. Having a collectible equipped doesn't let you interact with anything and the button layout for moves is somewhat awkward. Not much more to say here. 

Verdict: 8

Psychonauts is an enjoyable game for hardcore fans and casual gamers alike. While it doesn't come close to matching the quality and prestige of other titles of the same genre, it does retain a unique identity and a creative world that manages to remain original in its concept. Despite its many problems with the gameplay, the game still provides a fun adventure that is worth playing, even if it's just for a few hours.

109278578.review:
After gathering mold in my Steam library for years, it was finally time to play through the game. And how was it? Very good. Not flawless, but enjoyable enough for me to WANT to play through it, instead of forcing myself to.

The opening does a lot of good jobs at once - it establishes the premise (secret agents with psychic powers), eases the player into the mood and aesthetic of the game, and even sprinkles in some foreshadowing for what's to come. 
Admittedly, the aesthetic was pretty tricky to get used to for me at first, but I eventually learned to love it - it's basically an amazing 2000s kids media capsule, reminding me a lot of properties such as Spy Kids and Invader Zim. The game's visuals have aged considerably, a lot of models stand out as extra low poly with blurry textures, and the cutscenes are low-res beyond expectation, but the game still holds up pretty strong in the art direction departament, which makes some locations stand out even by modern standards.
The mood and the ambience also deserve praise. The music loops are rather short, but they seem to really try and max out the creativity to compliment whatever is currently happening (though there are some misses, the "Basic Braining" theme is rather tiring to listen to for example).

As a lifelong Rayman fan, I felt right at home in this package of a game. There's platforming that involves jumps, double jumps, hovering, ledge-grabbing, ladders, rope-walking and trapezium swings, and you learn most of these mechanics in the first tutorial. It felt a bit bloated and gimmicky, and I never shook the feeling off entirely, but in the end all of Raz's abilities ended up serving a thematic purpose in the plot, which is very neat and even a bit surprising.
As all the well-made 3D platformers do, this game includes a permanent dot shadow fixed directly under the character, helping you navigate space mid-air and know exactly where will you land, which is very helpful considering how weird movement in this game can get. Not only because you can mix and match abilities and the maps can twist and warp in numerous occassions, but also because sometimes the camera decides to become your mortal enemy.

The combat felt a bit mediocre, mostly due to major clarity issues, but that might be my "being spoiled by Dark Souls" talking. Clarity issues are a major flaw in the game in general - sometimes it's hard to tell what's an insignificant background element and what's not, and sometimes the game expects you to use such elements without ever easing you into the idea, so prepare to look up "what do I do here" a few times along the way. But maybe that's entirely my fault for under-utilizing the power of [b]Bacon[/b].

In the end, this is a great game. 7-12 hours of a solid, pretty much no-filler experience, with a very original aesthetic, pretty fresh subject matter (portraying mental health in a lighthearted, family friendly way without trivializing the issues portrayed nor making ill people the butt of the joke) and a feel good plot full of sassy characters. It can get a bit annoying at times, but most of it are just good memories in the making. Worth a buy? Yes.

Now excuse while I go and play the sequel, finally armed with context.

109131745.review:
Everytime I think of a 3D platformers I usually feel weary, it’s such a easy genre to get tired of. And yet playing them usually speak otherwise, that is until it finally starts to tire you out; this is what I call the early 2000s 3D platformer effect, you have fun until the thought of playing it drains every inch of mental energy that you have. Mario Sunshine, Battle for Bikini Bottom, etc, all suffer from draining the player and not making them want more.

Psychonauts is the exception to this, and is one of the few platformers that after it’s over, you actively want to go back to try and finish everything. It’s such a creative & wonderful game, the levels are inspired, the world is nice, and I swear this is one of the funniest games I’ve ever played because it pulls no punches. 

And having a game that focuses so hard on mental issues in a delightful way is so nice. It’s never too depressing, but it’s never takes away from these issues with it’s humor.  Not only that, part of me can relate deeply with some of these characters (*cough* Edgar *cough*) and minimal spoilers but the final bit that has you helping a character overcome deep seated trauma is so beautifully done.

It’s not perfect though, it takes a moment to get to the really good levels, and the final level is disappointing considering that 4 of the last 5 levels before it were masterpieces, combat is underutilized and never that great, and apart from like Raz, Sasha, and a couple other characters - the character design sucks. 

Regardless of all those this game is one of the best 3D platformers of all time, and my second favorite from the 2000s era (Mario Galaxy is unbeatable in my eyes haha)

On a scale of Messy Divorce to ‘Till Death Do We Part I give this game a Happy Loving Marriage.

In other words 9/10.

109081198.review:
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38888018-United-Critics/] Please follow [b]United Critics[/b] for quality reviews[/url]

[h1]Psychonauts Review[/h1]
Before I start with the review, let me save you some time, if you are not ok with outdated graphics and some game mechanics, this game is not for you.

Psychonauts tells the story of Rasputin, a young psychic that wants to become a Psychonaut (a secret agent with psychic powers). The game takes place during the span of 2 days in a secret training facility that looks like a summer camp full of kids with all kinds of wacky powers and weird personalities. And that is all I will tell you, I went blind into this game and I have to say that the less you know about the lore, the more you’ll enjoy it.

[h1] Questions you might have if you're interested in playing it: [/h1]

[list]
[*][b]What is it exactly that you do in the game?[/b]
If you know about classic 3D platformers from the early 2000’s, you will get what Psychonauts is all about. If not, it’s basically a game mostly oriented on traversing the levels jumping and collecting all kinds of junk in order to gain or improve skills.

[*][b] Will it make my eyes bleed?[/b]
It’s a 20-year-old game, so yes… but not quite… As low quality as the textures may look for modern standards, the art style and cinematics alongside the in-game animations still hold up surprisingly well.

I personally love how stylized the in-game models are. From a character design perspective, they are easily recognizable and you can tell who they are just by how they look, they did an amazing work.

I’m a person that thinks that graphics are the least important aspect of a game and I really don’t mind old graphics, but if you are sensitive to “ugly” graphics, you will hate this game.

[*][b]Does it have a good story?[/b]
Not really. The story is fun but predictable. The game has a huge plus in its favor: it has a ton of enjoyable characters and an amazing sense of humor.

I would say that the story of the game is enjoyable but nothing fantastic.

[*][b]Does it have a good soundtrack?[/b]
The OST helps to compliment the theme of each level very well but is not memorable or catchy. It’s a decent OST that doesn’t do anything special, It’s like the background music in the Saturday cartoons.

[*][b]Does it have replay value?[/b]
Gameplay-wise: If you want to replay the levels to pick up every single collectable, then yes. Beyond that it has no replay-ability.

But from the thematic aspect of the game, it’s worth replaying this game to see all the little details that the devs put into each world and how everything connects with each other. There are so many cool little details that you can understand in a second play-through that it truly makes a revisit worth it.

[*][b]Does it run well?[/b]
Yes. It does have some minor bugs and glitches, but nothing game breaking. For being a game from the early 2000’s it runs flawlessly in modern systems without you needing to mod or tweak something. This is a thing that is rare among older games.

[*][b]Is it fun?[/b]
Yes! This game is so funny and creative with how it implements their themes and ideas. Gameplay-wise is just another early 2000’s 3D platformer, nothing bad with that, but this game shines on how the world, the characters and the subtext is presented to you.

Gameplay wise it's your standard 3D platformer, but thematically it’s easily one of the richest and fun games that I have ever played.

The parts where the game makes you deduce what to do next having new abilities at your disposal are hands down the most enjoyable.

Be aware that the last level is a glorified escort mission and it is annoying as hell, this may be a game that you will enjoy playing but not finishing.
[/list]

[h1] So what is Psychonauts?[/h1]
The term that I see a lot of people use for this type of game is “collectathon”, for those that don’t know a collectathon is a game that requires you to pick up lots of random collectables to progress the main story, usually it’s a 3D platformer. Psychonauts asks you to only get some of the thousands of collectibles to finish the game with the basic set of skills, but the game becomes way easier and definitively way more enjoyable.

One of the things that really impressed me about this title has to be how it presents their themes about the mind and how it feels to be inside another person's mind. I’m not going to write an in depth analysis about it here, but I would like to highlight some spoiler free concepts that may help you to understand what I mean:

-There is a world halfway through the game that represents the broken mind of a crazy man, which is composed of 3 sub worlds. The first world exists inside the second world, the second world exists inside the third world and the third word exists within the first world. Besides being an amazing concept of a level to explore, it helps to reinforce how this crazy person is trapped inside his own mind.

-Most levels are dedicated to explore and (most of the time) help people overcome their problems. Almost everything inside each mind is unique, including the collectables that tell you small bits of that person's life. Once you figure out what they are all about, you start to see how everything fits, it’s brilliant.

The game is not perfect; the controls are where the game feels the most outdated. Some animations take too long to complete and certain elements of the levels or the design of the enemies can and will stun-lock you.

[h1] Things that I like about this game:[/h1]
[list]
[*]It’s an almost bug free experience. This game is so polished!

[*]The boss battles are amazing

[*]One of the most creative level designs that I have ever seen in a game.

[*]The animations are amazing.

[*]The difficulty curve is perfect.

[*]The powers are fun to use and they affect gameplay in meaningful ways.

[*]One of the most funny games that I have ever played. This is not hyperbole, it truly is.

[*]You can skip all cinematics, be mindful that for older games this is a huge plus.

[*]Works perfectly with modern OS.

[/list]

[h1] Things that I dislike about this game:[/h1]
[list]
[*]The platforming is a bit too stiff and updated for my taste.

[*]For the most part it is not that hard, but when you hit a wall this game can be so frustrating.

[/list]
[h1] Is this game worth my hard earned money?[/h1]
If you came this far I assume you don’t mind old and “ugly” graphics. So if you are intro 3D platformers, or you are looking for a weird and creative game this is an easy buy. I can see why this game has a cult classic status, it’s a surprisingly mature and funny experience.

This is the kind of game that everyone can enjoy, but not everyone will play. Give it a try, it is worth it.

Rating: 8/10

General Thoughts:

Great game ruined by a few absolutely stupid elements in the game design.

The absolute worst thing about this game which I knocked a point off for, Once you leave the open world camp area for the main story, you can't ever go back. If you missed out on collectibles it's too late, new game. The biggest issue here is that the game first establishes this camp as an open world, in-between levels area. Which on it's own is fine... until you accidentally reach a point where you can't go back? like seriously who designs a game like that? There is a way to go back to each level and retrieve those items, why not the open world part? this is so dumb it actually hurts my brain.

The hint system is an absolute joke. The hint you get is the over arching suggestion for where to go next or what you need to do. The problem is if you know you need item x to do this, but you have no idea where item x is, or how to go about it, you get 0 help.

There are a number of enemies in the game that are more tedious than anything. Most notable being the rats that explode and do a wack ton of damage, if you mess up and get hit by one, since you're disoriented, its extremely likely that they'll all damage you. It's the worst.

Level design is amazing. Each level is unique, fun, sometimes too challenging to know what to do (see earlier comment) but they all have a unique spin to the characters personality which I absolutely loved. This game has some of the most memorable moments of any platform game I've ever played. Most games lack these elements which is sad that the only thing holding this game back is some terrible decisions as I outlined above.

108638401.review:
If you grew up on Rocko's Modern Life, KABLAM!, Invader Zim, Chowder, etc. you owe it to yourself to at least give this a try. It's like a blast from the past and I'm back in my childhood days. The quirky and spontaneous characters are what draws you to the game.

The highlight for me is that, this has, by far, the most mature and yet easily digestible depiction on how to move on from heartbreak, in a game that I have ever seen.

The platforming is easily the worst part of the game. The problem is that it's almost perfect, but there's like a 1 out of 10 chance that your character gets stuck in some geometry, air control would feel inconsistent, double jump not working at all, or lifting yourself up from a zipline having an annoying delay. This can lead to some frustrating deaths, especially in the last parts of the game. But if you can weather through that, you'll be treated to one of the best gaming experiences that harken back to the old Nick cartoons.

108026519.review:
I absolutely adore the concept of the game, and some of the levels are standouts (everyone loves Milkman Conspiracy, and my personal favorite is Black Velvetopia), but the negatives are plentiful. The camera makes me motion sick, the platforming isn't precise (which is an issue because there's parts of the game that demand it), inputs get eaten at critical points sometimes, the figments aren't fun to collect, the characterization of the people you don't explore the minds of (re: campers) is flat and annoying, the UI was clunky, the music isn't anything to write home about, and the plot feels contrived considering the complexity of the premise. The puzzles are decent for the most part (there are CERTAINLY exceptions - Gloria's Theater can suck it) but it's nothing I can recommend in good conscience. I have heard most of this is fixed in the sequel, so honestly I'd just play that instead.

That said, in terms of positives, the level design is fantastic. The symbolism and wackiness interwoven into the story is truly genius. But it doesn't outweigh everything else.

TL;DR: Brilliant concept, botched execution.
